The [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] term is ''позафракційний'' which literally means ''out of a faction''.|group=nb}} [[People's Deputy of Ukraine|member]] of the [[7th Ukrainian Verkhovna Rada|current]] [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian parliament]], former [[Defence minister|Minister of Defence]], member of the [[Our Ukraine (political party)|Our Ukraine]] political party and leader of the [[Civil Position]] party.{{uk icon}} [http://da-ta.com.ua/mon_mainnews/918.htm Політична партія „Громадянська позиція“], Database DA-TA[http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/21256/ Western Ukrainian intelligentsia calls on candidates for president to withdraw in favor of Tymoshenko] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314005853/http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/21256/ |date=March 14, 2012 }}, [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (October 1, 2009)[http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/index.php?id=148&listid=80493 Civil Position organization has chance to become 160th political party] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205233049/http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/index.php?id=148&listid=80493 |date=December 5, 2010 }}, [[Radio Ukraine]] (December 11, 2008) ==Education== Hrytsenko graduated with honours from [[Kiev Military Aviation Engineering Academy|Kyiv Higher Military Aviation Engineering School]] on 23 June 1979.{{cite web|url=http://www.mil.gov.ua/images/event/minob_vvnz.jpg |title=Diploma of Kyiv Military Aviation School |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070321030156/http://www.mil.gov.ua/images/event/minob_vvnz.jpg |archivedate=2007-03-21 }} On 10 December 1984 he was awarded a [[Candidate of Sciences]] (Ph.D.) degree from Kyiv Higher Military Aviation Engineering School.{{cite web|url=http://www.mil.gov.ua/images/event/minob_candidat.jpg |title=PhD from Kyiv Military Aviation School |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070321030236/http://www.mil.gov.ua/images/event/minob_candidat.jpg |archivedate=2007-03-21 }} And in 1993 Hrytsenko graduated from the [[Defense Language Institute]] of the [[United States Department of Defense]]. On 6 June 1994 he graduated from the Resident Program of the [[Air War College|U.S. Air War College]]{{cite web|url=http://www.mil.gov.ua/images/event/minob_usa.jpg |title=Diploma of Air University |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070321030132/http://www.mil.gov.ua/images/event/minob_usa.jpg |archivedate=2007-03-21 |df= }} And on 30 October 1995 Hrytsenko graduated from the Academy of the [[Armed Forces of Ukraine]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mil.gov.ua/images/event/minob_stnauk.jpg |title=Diploma of Academy of the Armed Forces of Ukraine |dead-url=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070321030206/http://www.mil.gov.ua/images/event/minob_stnauk.jpg |archivedate=2007-03-21 |df= }} Hrytsenko is author of more than 100 scientific papers published in [[Ukraine]], Belgium, the [[Netherlands]], United States, Germany and Switzerland.{{ru icon}} [http://file.liga.net/person/330-anatolii-gricenko.html Short bio], LIGA ==Army career== Hrytsenko served 25 years in the [[Armed Forces of Ukraine]], he served in combat units, as teacher at the military college and in staff positions in the [[Ministry of Defense of Ukraine]]. Hrytsenko's rank was colonel. From December 1999 till 2004 he worked as a military consultant in various firms. In February 2000 Hrytsenko served as Freelance Consultant on the Committee on National Security and Defence of the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's parliament) and in November 2000 as a member of the Public Council of Experts on domestic issues of the [[President of Ukraine]]. ==Political career== In 2004 Hrytsenko worked in the election headquarters (for the [[2004 Ukrainian presidential election]]) of [[Viktor Yushchenko]] and took an active part in the writing his election program. Hrytsenko became [[Defence minister|Minister of Defence]] in the [[First Tymoshenko Government]] in February 2005, he continued this position in the [[Yekhanurov Government]]. On 4 August 2006 he was appointed again as head of the Ministry of Defence in the [[Alliance of National Unity|government of]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] on the quota of President Yushchenko. In the [[Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2007|early 2007 parliamentary elections]] he was elected into the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Ukraine's parliament) as number 4 on the party list of the pro-president Yushchenko [[Our Ukraine–People's Self-Defense Bloc]]. Although this bloc was part of the [[Second Tymoshenko Government]] [[Yuriy Yekhanurov]] became Minister of Defense in this cabinet.[http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-316572.html Tymoshenko asks President to dismiss Yekhanurov as Defense Minister], [[UNIAN]] (May 20, 2009)[https://archive.is/20130205033806/http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/198961.html Tymoshenko Initiating Yekhanurov’s Dismissal], [[Ukrainian News Agency]] (May 20, 2009)[https://archive.is/20120919014803/http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/198990.html Minister Yekhanurov Not Intending To Step Down], [[Ukrainian News Agency]] (May 20, 2009)[http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/14141/ Yekhanurov denies reports of corrupt schemes at defense ministry], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (May 20, 2009) In January 2010 Hrytsenko became party leader of ''[[Civil Position]]''.{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2010/02/12/4759622/ Hritsenko will go on at the head of the party renamed?], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (February 12, 2010) Hrytsenko was a candidate for [[President of Ukraine]] in the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|2010 Ukrainian presidential elections]],{{cite web|url=http://en.ura-inform.com/elections/2009/05/28/griz_pres |title=Hrytsenko joins the fight for the presidency |accessdate=2009-06-15 |date=May 28, 2009 |work=URA-Inform |language=Russian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717171809/http://en.ura-inform.com/elections/2009/05/28/griz_pres |archivedate=July 17, 2011 }} during the election he received 1,2% of the votes (finishing ninth).{{uk icon}} [http://gazeta.ua/index.php?id=324402 ЦВК оприлюднила офіційні результати 1-го туру виборів], Gazeta.ua (January 25, 2010) In the second round he called on voting against both candidates ([[Yulia Tymoshenko]] and [[Viktor Yanukovych]]).[https://www.utoronto.ca/jacyk/ElectionWatch/Blog/Entries/2010/1/29_Tymoshenkos_Looming_Defeat__How_Did_She_Make_It_Inevitable-_Serhiy_Kudelia.html Tymoshenko’s Looming Defeat: How Did She Make It Inevitable?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111222814/http://www.utoronto.ca/jacyk/ElectionWatch/Blog/Entries/2010/1/29_Tymoshenkos_Looming_Defeat__How_Did_She_Make_It_Inevitable-_Serhiy_Kudelia.html |date=2013-11-11 }}, Serhiy Kudelia (January 29, 2010) ''Civil Position'' [[Ternopil Oblast local election, 2009#Ternopil city council|gained one seat]] in the [[Ternopil]] city council during the [[Ukrainian local elections, 2010|2010 Ukrainian local elections]].{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2010/11/8/5552584/ Results of the elections, preliminary data, on interactive maps] by [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (November 8, 2010) [[File:Anatoliy Hrytsenko 2012.jpg|thumb|Hrytsenko in October 2012]] During the [[2012 Ukrainian parliamentary election]] Hrytsenko was elected into the Verkhovna Rada as 3rd on the electoral list of [[Batkivshchyna]].{{uk icon}} [http://www.pravda.com.ua/articles/2012/11/11/6977259/ Список депутатів нової Верховної Ради], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (11 November 2012)[http://ukrainianweek.com/Politics/58995 They Call Themselves the Opposition], [[The Ukrainian Week]] (31 August 2012)[http://www.unian.info/news/535322-hrytsenko-refused-to-sign-statement-of-opposition.html Hrytsenko refused to sign statement of opposition] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116080516/http://www.unian.info/news/535322-hrytsenko-refused-to-sign-statement-of-opposition.html |date=January 16, 2014 }}, [[UNIAN]] (13.11.2012) Hrytsenko did not sign the November 2012 oppositional forces Batkivshchyna, [[UDAR]] and [[Svoboda (party)|Svoboda]] joint action plan "I did not sign this document because I offered another action plan, but it was not supported”; but did state he would fulfil it. On 18 May 2013 the faction of Batkivshchyna demanded that Hrytsenko (who was a member of the Batkivshchyna faction) would resign from parliament.[http://www.interfax.co.uk/ukraine-news/batkivschyna-demands-hrytsenko-resign-as-mp/ Batkivschyna demands Hrytsenko resign as MP], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (18 June 2013) Hrytsenko agreed to do that if Batkivshchyna faction leader [[Arseniy Yatseniuk]] would do the same.[http://utr.tv/eng/news-from-www-ukrinform-ua/305308-hrytsenko_agrees_to_abandon_parliamentary_seat_305308.html Hrytsenko agrees to abandon parliamentary seat]{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Ukrainian Television and Radio]] (18 June 2013) Hrytsenko eventually left the faction on 14 January 2014 "Due to [my] inability to influence the decisions that are taken by the Batkivschyna faction".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/185681.html MP Hrytsenko leaving Batkivschyna faction], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] ( January 2014) Yatseniuk immediately responded by saying the faction hoped that after leaving the faction Hrytsenko would resign from parliament (also); and also added "People blinded by their own ambitions do much harm to the team's struggle".[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/185701.html Batkivschyna faction leader expects Hrytsenko to resign from parliament], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (14 January 2014) On 17 January 2014 Hrytsenko submitted a letter of resignation to parliament.[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/186270.html Hrytsenko resigns from parliament], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (17 January 2014) Hrytsenko was one of the candidates for presidency in the [[2014 Ukrainian presidential election]]. According to the opinion poll ordered by [[1+1 (channel)|1+1]] TV channel and conducted by [[GfK|GfK Ukraine]] on 6–8 May, 5.6 per cent of the surveyed would cast their votes for him.{{cite web |url=http://news.finance.ua/ua/~/1/0/all/2014/05/12/325540 |title=Порошенко тотально лідирує в електоральних симпатіях українців, Тігіпко трохи випереджає Тимошенко - опитування GFK |publisher=Finance.ua |language=uk |accessdate=16 May 2014 |date=12 May 2014}} In the election he received 5.48% of the vote, ranking him in 4th place.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/566632/ |title=Poroshenko wins presidential election with 54.7% of vote - CEC |publisher=[[Radio Ukraine International]] |date=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529212731/http://www.nrcu.gov.ua/en/148/566632/ |archivedate=29 May 2014 }}
{{ru icon}} [http://telegraf.com.ua/ukraina/politika/1300294-rezultatyi-vyiborov-prezidenta-ukrainyi-2014-tsik-obrabotala-51-99.html Results election of Ukrainian president], Телеграф (29 May 2014) == Accusations in army collapse == In October 2006, after the [[Prosecutor General of Ukraine|Prosecutor General’s Office of Ukraine]] criticized the Ministry of Defense for the ineffective fight against [[corruption]] and crime in the army, Hrytsenko summoned Prosecutor General [[Oleksandr Medvedko]] to a live TV debates.{{cite web | url = https://www.pravda.com.ua/rus/news/2006/10/20/4407133/ |title=Два телеканала предложили демонстрировать дуэль Гриценко и Медведько. | publisher = ''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]'' | date = 20 October 2006 | accessdate = 29 November 2018 | language = ru}} Two Ukrainian TV channels offered their broadcasts for those debates. The head of the press service of the General Prosecutor's Office said that the Prosecutor General's Office is not a political structure to participate in the TV debates, and the Ministry of Defense is an institution under the control of the Prosecutor General's Office. It was decided to hold a joint board of the Prosecutor General's Office and the Ministry of Defense, at which journalists will be able to attend.{{cite news|url=https://www.unian.net/politics/20117-medvedko-sdelal-gritsenko-vstrechnoe-predlojenie.html|title=Медведько сделал Гриценко встречное предложение|date=20 October 2006|publisher=''[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]]''|language=ru|accessdate=29 November 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://korrespondent.net/ukraine/politics/167843-medvedko-otkazal-gricenko-v-dueli|title=Медведько отказал Гриценко в «дуэли»|date=20 October 2006|publisher=korrespondent.net|language=ru|accessdate=29 November 2018}} After that Hrytsenko urged the Prosecutor General to resign.{{cite news|url=https://fraza.ua/news/30529-medvedko-ne-poydet-v-otstavku-gricenko-dlya-nego-ne-avtoritet|title=Медведько не пойдет в отставку. Гриценко для него не авторитет|date=10 November 2006|publisher=fraza.ua|language=ru|accessdate=29 November 2018}} In May 2014 the General Prosecutor Office of Ukraine stated that Anatoliy Hrytsenko’s actions (as one of ex-Ministers of Defense) have brought the Armed Forces of Ukraine to the state of inappropriate combat readiness. The criminal proceedings have been opened.{{Cite web|url=https://www.segodnya.ua/politics/gpu-otkryla-ugolovnoe-proizvodstvo-v-otnoshenii-kandidata-v-prezidenty-gricenko-522502.html|title=ГПУ открыла уголовное производство в отношении кандидата в президенты Гриценко|publisher=''[[Segodnya]]'' |date=22 May 2014|accessdate=27 November 2018|language=ru}}{{Cite web|url=https://gordonua.com/news/politics/protiv-eks-ministrov-oborony-zaveli-delo-po-podozreniyu-v-snizhenii-oboronosposobnosti-strany-23794.html|title=Против экс-министров обороны завели дело по подозрению в снижении обороноспособности страны|publisher=gordonua.com |date=22 May 2014|accessdate=27 November 2018|language=ru}} People’s deputy, leader of the [[Svoboda (political party)|Svoboda]] political party, [[Oleh Tyahnybok]], revealed some details of this criminal case: during the time when Hrytsenko was in charge of the Ministry of Defense, "1,000 units of [[9K31 Strela-1|Strela]], [[9K32 Strela-2|Strela-2]], Strela-M, and [[9K38 Igla|Igla]] [[Man-portable air-defense system|MPADS]], which were based in [[Shostka]], disappeared. The Prosecutor General's Office opened a criminal case and investigates these issues." Tyahnybok also added that under Hrytsenko, the [[Buk missile system|Buk-M1]] and [[S-300 missile system|S-300]] complexes disappeared in an unknown direction.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theinsider.ua/rus/politics/537d0c2f7ace3/|title=ГПУ возбудила дело по исчезновению вооружения в Минобороны времен Гриценко|publisher=''The Insider'' | date = 21 May 2014|accessdate=27 November 2018|language=ru}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.pravda.com.ua/rus/news/2014/05/21/7026057/|title=Генпрокуратура открыла дело, которое касается Гриценко — Тягнибок|publisher=''[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]'' | date = 21 May 2014 | accessdate = 27 November 2018 | language = ru}}{{Cite web | url = https://24tv.ua/ru/gpu_otkrila_delo_kotoroe_kasaetsya_minoboroni_vremen_gritsenko__tyagnibok_n445386 | title = ГПУ открыла дело, которое касается Минобороны времен Гриценко, — Тягнибок | publisher = Channel 24 | date = 21 May 2014 | accessdate = 27 November 2018 | language = ru}} In 2016, the General Prosecutor Office of Ukraine published materials of investigation “Russian war aggression against Ukraine”. According to published data, when Anatoliy Hrytsenko served as minister of defense war equipment had been sold out amounted to the sum of UAH 1,316.17 million.{{Cite web | url = https://zik.ua/ru/news/2018/02/22/pry_pravlenyy_kakyh_mynystrov_unychtozhyly_bolshe_vooruzhenyy_ukraynskoy_armyy_1271505 | title = При правлении каких министров уничтожено больше всего вооружения Украинской Армии | publisher = ''ZIK'' | date = 22 February 2018 | accessdate = 28 November 2018 | language = ru}} The investigation states that this has been one of the main factors which led to the [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|Crimea Crisis]] and [[War in Donbass]]. Several journalist investigations state that Anatoliy Hrytsenko was involved in corruption schemes of selling of military encampments and other military objects as well as discarding military property.{{Cite news|url=http://expres.ua/main/2016/06/02/188374-skilky-zh-pocupyv-posadi-ministr-oborony-grycenko|title=Скільки ж поцупив на посаді міністр оборони Гриценко?|publisher =Експрес-онлайн|date=2 June 2016|accessdate=15 May 2018 | language = uk}} The investigation of the 1NEWS agency shows that during the period when Anatoliy Hrytsenko was a Minister, the Ministry of Defense lost 27 military towns. In addition, journalists learned that the peak of arms exports from Ukraine to other countries fell for [[2006]]. Ukraine sold 634 [[missile]]s and [[rocket launcher]]s, 83 [[Vehicle armour|armored vehicles]], as well as 38 [[tank]]s. In 2007, Ukraine sold weapons to [[Russia]] for [[United States dollar|US$]] 100 million.{{Cite news|url=https://1news.com.ua/actualne/anatoliy-gritsenko-pershiy-neprohidniy-abo-yak-rozkradalasya-armiya.html|title=Анатолій Гриценко: перший непрохідний або як розкрадалася армія | publisher = 1news.com.ua | date = 20 December 2016 | accessdate = 28 November 2018 | language = uk}} On April 4, 2018, National Anti-Corruption Bureau of Ukraine (NABU) informed that the Specialized Anti-Corruption Prosecutor Office initiated a criminal proceeding based on results of state financial audit of "Viysktorhservis" consortium.{{Cite news|url=https://www.unian.net/politics/10140281-smi-nashli-dokumenty-o-somnitelnoy-prodazhe-gricenko-24-ga-zemli-vsu-v-kieve.html|title=СМИ нашли документы о сомнительной продаже Гриценко 24 га земли ВСУ в Киеве|publisher=''[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]]''|access-date=2018-06-06|language=ru}} An investigation conducted by website "Argument" found out documents signed by Hrytsenko. According to these documents, in 2005-2007 Hrytsenko sold 24 hectares of land on the Stolychne highway owned by the Ministry of Defense to ex-mayor of Kyiv [[Leonid Chernovetsky]]. According to journalists, Chernovetsky took an active part in this criminal transaction.{{Cite news|url=https://www.unian.net/politics/10140281-smi-nashli-dokumenty-o-somnitelnoy-prodazhe-gricenko-24-ga-zemli-vsu-v-kieve.html|title=СМИ нашли документы о сомнительной продаже Гриценко 24 га земли ВСУ в Киеве|publisher=''[[Ukrainian Independent Information Agency|UNIAN]]''|date=4 June 2018|accessdate=24 November 2018|language=ru}}{{Cite news|url=https://zik.ua/ru/news/2018/06/04/na_dokumentah_svydetelstvuyushchyh_o_zemelnih_mahynatsyyah_obnaruzhyly_lychnuyu_1338135|title=На документах, свидетельствующих о земельных махинациях, обнаружили личную подпись экс-министра обороны |publisher=''ZIK Channel''|date=4 June 2018|accessdate=24 November 2018|language=ru}}{{Cite news|url=https://vesti-ukr.com/politika/298673-najdeny-dokumenty-o-somnitelnoj-prodazhe-hritsenko-24-ha-zemli-vsu-v-kieve-smi|title=Опубликованы документы о сомнительной продаже Гриценко 24 га земли ВСУ в Киеве - УНИАН |publisher=''[[Vesti (Ukrainian newspaper)|Vesti]]''|date=13 August 2018|accessdate=24 November 2018|language=ru}} ==Awards== * Honorary weapon – [[Fort-12]] pistol (25 October 2007){{cite web|url=http://zakon.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/1019/2007|title=Указ Президента України № 1019/2007 від 25 жовтня 2007 року «Про нагородження А. Гриценка відзнакою „Іменна вогнепальна зброя“»|publisher=[[Verkhovna Rada]]|date=25 October 2007|accessdate=26 November 2018|language=uk}}{{cite web|url=https://rg.ru/2008/09/04/orujie-nagrady.html|title=Наган от министра|author=Igor Yelkov|publisher=''[[Rossiyskaya Gazeta]]''|date=4 September 2008|accessdate=26 November 2018|language=ru}} ==Personal life== Hrytsenko is married to [[Yulia Mostova|Yulia Volodymyrivna Mostova]], a chief editor of well known Ukrainian newspaper ''[[Dzerkalo Tyzhnia]]'' and a widow of [[Oleksandr Razumkov]]. ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=nb}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Anatoliy Stepanovych Hrytsenko}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110724093050/http://www.taraskuzio.net/uafree_files/UA_2.3.pdf Biography] by [[Taras Kuzio]] * {{uk icon}} [http://www.grytsenko.com.ua/ Personal web-site] {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{succession box | title=[[List of Ministers of Defense (Ukraine)|Minister of Defense]] | before=[[Oleksandr Kuzmuk]] | after=[[Yuriy Yekhanurov]] | years=2005-2007}} {{s-end}} {{Ukrainian Ministers of Defence}} {{2010 presidential election candidates, Ukraine}} {{2014 presidential election candidates, Ukraine}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hrytsenko, Anatoliy}} [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Zvenyhorodka Raion]] [[Category:Our Ukraine (political party) politicians]] [[Category:Defence ministers of Ukraine]] [[Category:Defense Language Institute alumni]] [[Category:Candidates for President of Ukraine (2010)]] [[Category:People of the Euromaidan]] [[Category:Batkivshchyna politicians]] [[Category:Candidates for President of Ukraine (2014)]] [[Category:21st-century Ukrainian politicians]]

According to [[Christian]] tradition, [[John the Apostle]] ordained Antipas as [[bishop of Pergamon]] during the reign of the Roman emperor [[Domitian]]. The traditional account goes on to say Antipas was [[martyr]]ed during the reign of Nero (54-68),[https://oca.org/saints/lives/2013/04/11/101052-hieromartyr-antipas-the-bishop-of-pergamum-and-disciple-of-st-join "Hieromartyr Antipas the Bishop of Pergamum and Disciple of St John the Theologian", Orthodox Church in America] by burning in a [[brazen bull|brazen bull-shaped altar]] for casting out demons worshiped by the local population. {{About|the literary concept|ethical shortcomings in real people|Vice}} {{Unreferenced|date=September 2008}} In the creation and criticism of fictional works, a '''character flaw''' is a limitation, imperfection, problem, [[phobia]], or deficiency present in a character who may be otherwise very functional. The flaw can be a problem that directly affects the character's actions and abilities, such as a violent temper. Alternatively, it can be a simple foible or personality defect, which affects the character's motives and social interactions, but little else.
Flaws can add depth and humanity to the characters in a [[narrative]]. For example, the sheriff with a gambling addiction, the [[action hero]] who is afraid of heights, or a lead in a [[romantic comedy]] who must overcome his insecurity regarding male pattern baldness are all characters whose flaws help provide dimension. Perhaps the most widely cited and classic of character flaws is [[Achilles]]' famous heel.
In general, flaws can be categorized as ''minor'', ''major'', or ''tragic''.
==Minor flaw== A minor character flaw is an imperfection which serves to distinguish the character in the mind of the reader / viewer / player / listener, making them memorable and individual, but otherwise does not affect the story in any way.
Examples of this could include a noticeable scar, a thick accent or a habit such as cracking their knuckles.
[[Protagonists]] and other major characters may (and usually do) have multiple minor flaws, making them more accessible, and enabling the reader / viewer / listener to relate to the character (in the case of a [[sympathetic character]]) or otherwise influence the audience's opinions of the character.
Many insignificant or archetypal characters which are encountered only once or rarely are defined solely by a single minor flaw, differentiating them from the [[stock character]] or [[archetype]] that they adhere to.
==Major flaw== A major character flaw is a much more noticeable and important hindrance which actually impairs the individual, whether physically, mentally or morally. Sometimes major flaws are not actually negative per se (such as devout religious beliefs or a rigid code of honor), but are classified as such in that they often serve to hinder or restrict the character in some way.
Examples of this type of flaw could include blindness, [[amnesia]] or greed.
Unlike minor flaws, major flaws are almost invariably important to either the character's, or the story's development.
*For villains, their major flaw is usually the cause of their eventual downfall. *For heroes, their major flaw usually must be overcome (either temporarily or permanently) at some point in the story, often at the climax, by their own determination or skill. *For neutral characters, or those that shift allegiance, the major flaw is usually the cause of either their corruption, redemption or both. *For the protagonist, the most visible flaw generally serves a more vital interest, as well, as it defines his or her core problem. It is the protagonist's reluctant (and usually unconscious) journey to address this problem that forms the spine of the story, sometimes acting as the [[MacGuffin]] to stimulate the plot.
==Tragic/fatal flaw== This is a specific sort of flaw, also known as "[[Hamartia]]", which is possessed by Aristotelian [[tragic hero]]s. It is a flaw which causes an otherwise noble or exceptional character to bring about their own downfall and, often, their eventual death.
Examples of this could include [[hubris]], misplaced trust, excessive curiosity, pride and lack of self-control.
This fall usually occurs at the beginning of a story, with the story itself concentrates on the consequences or attempted redemption of the fall.
== Examples ==
===Literature=== *[[Oedipus|Oedipus's]] downfall is directly linked to arrogance: ''[[Oedipus Rex]]'' *Macbeth suffers from [[hubris]], leading to the murder of [[Duncan I of Scotland]]; he later becomes [[paranoia|paranoid]], leading him to order the deaths of [[Banquo]] and the family of [[Macduff (Macbeth)|Macduff]]: ''[[Macbeth]]'' *[[Hamlet]] is indecisive and self-doubting, which thwarts him in avenging his father's murder. *[[Victor Frankenstein]] suffers from excessive curiosity and irresponsibility, leading to the creation of the [[Frankenstein's monster|monster]] that destroys his life: ''[[Frankenstein]]'' *[[Sigurd]] has a vulnerable spot on his back, where a linden leaf fell as he was bathing in dragon's blood: ''[[Volsunga saga]]'' *[[Agamemnon]] acts in greed when he takes [[Briseis]] away from [[Achilles]], losing the warrior's support in the [[Trojan War]]: ''[[The Iliad]]''. Achilles's own flaw was his own arrogance. *[[Odysseus|Odysseus's]] flaw was an extreme [[Hubris (Ancient Greece)|hubris]] which led him to dishonor the god [[Poseidon]]. (''[[The Odyssey]]'') *[[Cyrano De Bergerac]], despite his many accomplishments, suffers from self-doubt because of his huge nose which keeps him from pursuing the woman he loves. *[[Marvin the Paranoid Android]] suffers from extreme depression, as well as extreme boredom due to his huge yet mostly inactive mind: ''[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]'' *[[Tom Riddle|Tom Riddle's]] extreme [[thanatophobia]] eventually transformed him into the vile Lord Voldemort in his pursuit for [[immortality]]. (''[[Harry Potter]]'') *[[Harry Potter]]'s worst flaws, as stated by Rowling, are "anger and occasional arrogance." However, within the text, it is implied his flaw might be his heroic desire to save people. (''[[Harry Potter]]'') *[[Percy Jackson]] has a fatal flaw of excessive personal loyalty, while his girlfriend Annabeth Chase shares the flaw of the legendary Odysseus: hubris. (''[[Percy Jackson and the Olympians]]'') *[[Jo March]]'s bluntness and hot temper cause conflict with her family. ''[[Little Women]]'' *In the ''[[Star Wars Expanded Universe|Star Wars Legends]]'' continuity, [[Jacen Solo|Jacen Solo's]] eventual downfall is linked to his placing the weight of the galaxy on his shoulder in his desire for peace.
===Film=== *In ''[[Rocky]]'', [[Rocky Balboa]] thinks of himself as a loser who cannot go the distance in the boxing ring. *[[Anakin Skywalker]]'s anger and fear of losing his wife [[Padme Amidala|Padme]] eventually consumes him, leading to his transformation into [[Darth Vader]]. Whereas his mentor [[Obi-Wan Kenobi|Obi-Wan Kenobi's]] compassion and love for his student blinded him to the path Skywalker was taking. (''[[Star Wars]]'') *In ''[[Casablanca (film)|Casablanca]]'', Rick thinks of himself as an unfeeling cynic who denies the pain and disappointment from a failed love affair with Ilsa. *In ''[[Vertigo (film)|Vertigo]]'', the detective played by [[James Stewart]] is afraid of heights and has to climb a tower. *[[Captain Hook]] is obsessed with ''[[Peter Pan]]'' *[[Characters in Blade Runner#Roy Batty|Roy Batty]], as a replicant, is powerful, but has a very short lifespan: ''[[Blade Runner]]'' *[[Oskar Schindler]] in the film ''[[Schindler's List]]'' must overcome his greedy nature and find compassion to sacrifice in order to save his workers
===Television=== *[[B. A. Baracus]] is afraid of flying: ''[[The A-Team]]'' *[[Homer Simpson]] is an alcoholic, not too bright and prone to reckless choices: ''[[The Simpsons]]'' *[[Philip J. Fry]] (usually) has a severe lack of intelligence: ''[[Futurama]]'' *[[Londo Mollari]] yearns to return to the "glory days" of the [[Centauri Republic]]: ''[[Babylon 5]]'' *[[Mr. Spock]] relies heavily on logic and suppresses his more human emotions: ''[[Star Trek]]'' *[[Drake Mallard|Darkwing Duck/Drake Mallard]] has a big ego. ''[[Darkwing Duck]]'' *[[Peter Griffin]] is extremely impulsive and causes many problems for his family and friends: ''[[Family Guy]]'' *[[Zuko]] makes misguided decisions in an effort to gain his cruel father's acceptance: ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'' *[[Aang]] is too carefree and initially attempts to run from his responsibilities rather than face them: ''[[Avatar: The Last Airbender]]'' *[[Dean Winchester]] relies on family and is devastated when he loses them or they betray his trust: ''[[Supernatural (U.S. TV series)|Supernatural]]'' *[[The Tenth Doctor]] is constantly trying to help and save the lives of others, and sometimes does things out of anger that have dire consequences later: ''[[Doctor Who]]'' *[[Mr. Gold|Rumplestiltskin's]] greatest character flaw was his greed, losing even those who love him over his mad desire for power. He shares this flaw with his former student and lover [[Cora Mills|Cora]]. (''[[Once Upon a Time (TV series)|Once Upon a Time]]'') *[[Zelena (Once Upon a Time)|Zelena's]] envy of her younger half-sister [[Regina Mills]] eventually transformed her into the infamous [[Wicked Witch of the West]] as she planned to reverse time and supplant Regina. Even after this plan was thwarted, her envy remained a great character flaw throughout her time on the show. (''[[Once Upon a Time (TV series)|Once Upon a Time]]'') *After the death of her fiance Daniel Colter, [[Regina Mills|Regina]] suffered a mental breakdown and became consumed with anger, which Rumplestiltskin was able to use to shape her into the Evil Queen who would cast his Dark Curse. Anger, as a fatal flaw, is one she shares with [[Hook (Once Upon a Time)|Killian Jones]] whose own anger transformed him into vengeful [[Captain Hook]]; however, Hook did not share Regina's mental instability. (''[[Once Upon a Time (TV series)|Once Upon a Time]]'') *The main character flaw of the protagonist of the series, [[Emma Swan]], are her tendency to mistrust other people, which leads her to put up emotional barriers to protect herself and run when things get difficult. Her overcoming this flaw is a major story arc on the show. (''[[Once Upon a Time (TV series)|Once Upon a Time]]'')
===Gaming=== * In [[Warhammer 40,000]], the Primarch Lorgar Aurelian is extremely devout and reveres his "father", the Emperor of Mankind, as a god. The Emperor envisages a human civilization free of the shackles of religion and dogma and chastises Lorgar and his legion for worshipping him. Hurt and depressed by the humiliation of his father's rebuke, Lorgar and the [[Space Marines (Warhammer 40,000)|Space Marines]] of the XVII Legion (the "Word Bearers") search for another purpose to sustain them, and in doing so become the first legion to fall under the malicious influence of [[Chaos (Warhammer)|Chaos]]. Their devotion to Chaos sees them instigate the devastating civil war known as the [[Horus Heresy (fictional event)|Horus Heresy]], the events of which led to the current dystopian setting of Warhammer 40,000. *In ''[[Metal Gear Solid]]'', Liquid's jealousy of Solid Snake's "dominant genes" and his desire to be the better of the two sets much of the story in motion, leading to Liquid's eventual downfall. *In the ''[[God of War (franchise)|God of War]]'' series, [[Kratos (God of War)|Kratos]] acts brutally and violently out of anger and desire for revenge, with devastating consequences on his only life and the world around him.

{{Infobox professional wrestler |name = Dave Hebner |names = |image = |image_size = |caption = |birth_name= David Hebner |height = |weight = |real_height = |real_weight = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1949|5|17}} |birth_place = [[Richmond, Virginia]] |death_date = |death_place = |resides = |billed = |trainer = |debut = 1963 |retired = |website = }} '''David Hebner''' (born May 17, 1949) is an [[United States|American]] [[professional wrestling]] [[Professional wrestling authority figures|authority figure]], [[Professional wrestling promotion|promoter]], [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Agent|road agent]], and [[Referee (professional wrestling)|referee]].
==Career== Hebner debuted as a professional wrestling referee in the late 1970s in the Richmond, Virginia area. In the 1980s he began working for the [[World Wrestling Entertainment|World Wrestling Federation]], where he refereed many historic matches such as [[Randy Savage]] versus [[Ricky Steamboat]] at [[WrestleMania III]] and Randy Savage versus [[Hulk Hogan]] at [[WrestleMania V]]. Perhaps his most memorable appearance came on the February 5, 1988 episode of ''[[WWE Saturday Night's Main Event|The Main Event]]'', when he was assigned to referee a match for the [[WWE Championship|WWF World Heavyweight Championship]] between Hulk Hogan and [[André the Giant]]. André defeated Hogan after Hebner's [[twin]] [[Sibling|brother]] [[Earl Hebner|Earl]] had switched places as Ted DiBiase had locked Dave in a closet. Earl Hebner quickly counted to three as André [[Pin (professional wrestling)|pinned]] Hogan, despite Hogan clearly having his shoulder up. The match and the WWF Championship were awarded to André as a result. Both Hebners received a [[United States dollar|$]]2,500 bonus for the match.
Prior to WrestleMania IV, the WWF attempted to extend the "evil twin" referee storyline through a [[kayfabe]] "[[investigative journalism|investigative report]]" published in the promotions' flagship publication, ''[[WWE Magazine|WWF Magazine]]''. The article used a fictional [[backstory]] to build sympathy for Dave by claiming he was continually victimized by Earl's misdeeds committed in Dave's name since their childhoods.<ref>"A ''WWF Magazine'' Investigative Report: Dave Hebner's Shadow," ''[[WWE Magazine|WWF Magazine]]'', June 1988, p. 30.</ref> In a 2001 interview with "WWF Raw Magazine", Dave Hebner said the angle was soon dropped after he had suffered broken ribs when Earl kicked him (as part of the aftermath of the Hogan-Andre match during ''The Main Event''). As a result, the storyline was shifted to have Earl come clean, and he was the referee when [[Randy Savage]] won the Tournament final at WrestleMania IV against Ted DiBiase for the WWF Championship.
After retiring as a referee following [[knee replacement surgery]], Hebner became a [[glossary of professional wrestling terms#Agent|road agent]]. He worked as a Road Agent until July 2005, when he was released from contract.
After being released, Hebner debuted in [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]] on the December 17, 2005 episode of ''[[TNA Impact!]]'', appearing on the stage during a match between [[The Dudley Boyz|Team 3D]] and [[The Diamonds in the Rough]].
Since 2012, Dave Hebner has been the manager of The Lumberjacks of MMWA Wrestling.
==Personal life== Hebner has been married to his wife Rebecca for 40 years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/2009/04/11/9085766.html|title=Nothing but the truth from Dave Hebner |accessdate=2009-05-05|publisher=Slam! Wrestling |date=2009-05-05}}</ref> Dave's identical twin brother [[Earl Hebner|Earl]] and nephew [[Brian Hebner|Brian]] (Earl's son) are also wrestling referees. Hebner has [[Parkinson's disease]].<ref>{{cite web|title=WWE sued in wrestler class action lawsuit featuring Jimmy ‘Superfly’ Snuka, Paul ‘Mr Wonderful’ Orndorff|url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/what-the-fox/wwe-sued-in-wrestler-class-action-lawsuit-featuring-jimmy-superfly-snuka-paul-mr-wonderful-orndorff/news-story/079fbd7db16f9cd71b7b569672baa4a5|work=[[FoxSports.com]]|date=July 18, 2015|accessdate=July 20, 2016|publisher=[[Fox Entertainment Group]] ([[21st Century Fox]])}}</ref>
In July 2016, Hebner was named part of a [[class action]] lawsuit filed against WWE which alleged that performers incurred "long term neurological injuries" and that the company "routinely failed to care" for them and "fraudulently misrepresented and concealed" the nature and extent of those injuries. The suit was litigated by attorney Konstantine Kyros, who has been involved in a number of other lawsuits against WWE.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/breaking/ct-wwe-cte-lawsuit-20160719-story.html|title=Dozens of wrestlers sue WWE over CTE, effects of traumatic brain injuries|last=Bieler|first=Des|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=July 20, 2016|date=July 19, 2016}}</ref> In September 2018, US District Judge [[Vanessa Lynne Bryant]] dismissed the lawsuit.<ref>{{cite web|title=Piledriver: WWE uses 'Hell in a Cell' as springboard to future shows|url=https://www.montgomeryadvertiser.com/story/sports/2018/09/22/wwe-uses-hell-cell-springboard-future-shows/1394073002/|work=[[Montgomery Advertiser]]|last=Robinson|first=Byron|date=September 22, 2018|accessdate=October 23, 2018}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox writer | name = David Foster Wallace | image = David Foster Wallace.jpg | caption = Wallace giving a reading in 2006 | birth_date = {{Birth date|1962|2|21}} | birth_place = [[Ithaca, New York]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|2008|9|12|1962|2|21}} | death_place = [[Claremont, California]], U.S. | occupation = Writer; university professor | alma_mater = [[Amherst College]]
[[University of Arizona]]
[[Harvard University]] | period = 1987–2008 | genre = [[Literary fiction]], [[non-fiction]] | movement = [[Postmodern literature]], [[post-postmodernism]], [[hysterical realism]], [[New Sincerity]] | notableworks = ''[[Infinite Jest]]'' (1996) }} '''David Foster Wallace''' (February 21, 1962 – September 12, 2008) was an American writer and university instructor in the disciplines of [[English studies|English]] and [[creative writing]]. His novel ''[[Infinite Jest]]'' (1996) was listed by ''Time'' magazine as one of the 100 best English-language novels published between 1923 and 2005.{{Cite news| last = Grossman| first = Lev| author-link1 = Lev Grossman |first2=Richard |last2 = Lacayo |author-link2=Richard Lacayo| title = All-TIME 100 Novels| newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | url = http://www.time.com/time/2005/100books/the_complete_list.html| date=October 16, 2005 | access-date=August 5, 2015}} His last novel, ''[[The Pale King]]'' (2011), was a finalist for the [[Pulitzer Prize for Fiction]] in 2012. The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''{{'}} David Ulin called Wallace "one of the most influential and innovative writers of the last twenty years".{{Cite news| title = Writer David Foster Wallace Found Dead| work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | first1=Claire| last1=Noland |first2=Joel |last2=Rubin| url = http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-wallace14-2008sep14,0,7461856.story| date =September 14, 2008 | access-date=August 5, 2015}} Among the writers who cite Wallace as an influence are [[Dave Eggers]],{{cite news |url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/jest-fest-2611625 |title=Jest Fest |work=[[LA Weekly]] |date=November 14, 2006}} [[Zadie Smith]],{{cite journal |url=https://newrepublic.com/article/books-and-arts/magazine/107209/reader-keep|title=Reader: Keep Up! The Identity Crisis of Zadie Smith|first=Ruth|last=Franklin|work=[[The New Republic]] |date=October 4, 2012 |accessdate=September 21, 2014}} [[Jonathan Franzen]],{{cite web|url=https://poetry.arizona.edu/blog/david-foster-wallace-elegy-jonathan-franzen |title=David Foster Wallace: An elegy by Jonathan Franzen |first=Jonathan |last=Franzen |authorlink=Jonathan Franzen |publisher=The University of Arizona Poetry Center |date=November 30, 2010|accessdate=September 21, 2014}} [[Elizabeth Wurtzel]],{{cite news |first=Elizabeth |last=Wurtzel |authorlink=Elizabeth Wurtzel |url=http://nymag.com/news/intelligencer/50515/|title=Elizabeth Wurtzel on Depression and David Foster Wallace|date=September 21, 2008|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|accessdate=September 21, 2014}} [[George Saunders]],{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/jan/02/noughties-writers-obituaries-review |title=Living in the Memory: A Celebration of the Great Writers Who Died in the Past Decade — David Foster Wallace (1962-2008) |first=George |last=Saunders |authorlink=George Saunders |date=January 2, 2010|work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=September 21, 2014}} [[Rivka Galchen]], [[Matthew Gallaway]], [[David Gordon (novelist)|David Gordon]], [[Darin Strauss]], [[Charles Yu]], and [[Deb Olin Unferth]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2011/04/07/david-foster-wallace-the-pale-king-roundtable-discussion.html|title=David Foster Wallace, The Pale King, Roundtable Discussion |first=Seth Colter |last=Walls |work=[[The Daily Beast]] |accessdate=September 21, 2014}} ==Life== David Foster Wallace was born in [[Ithaca, New York]], to Sally Jean Wallace ({{Nee|Foster}}) and [[James D. Wallace|James Donald Wallace]], and was raised in [[Champaign, Illinois]],Boswell and Burn, eds., p. 94. along with his younger sister, Amy Wallace-Havens.{{cite interview|last=Wallace-Havens|first=Amy|interviewer=Anne Strainchamps|title=Amy Wallace-Havens on Her Brother|url=http://www.ttbook.org/book/amy-wallace-havens-her-brother|publisher=[[WCAI]]|location=Woods Hole, Massachusetts|date=2009-08-23|work=[[To the Best of Our Knowledge]]|access-date=2018-04-19}} His father is an emeritus professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. His mother was a professor of English at [[Parkland College]], a community college in Champaign, which recognized her work with a "Professor of the Year" award in 1996. When Wallace was in fourth grade, his family moved to nearby [[Urbana, Illinois|Urbana]], where he attended Yankee Ridge Elementary School and [[Urbana High School (Illinois)|Urbana High School]]. As an adolescent, he was a regionally ranked junior tennis player, an experience he wrote about in the essay "Derivative Sport in Tornado Alley", originally published in ''[[Harper's Magazine]]'' as "Tennis, Trigonometry, Tornadoes". Although his parents were atheists, Wallace twice attempted to join the [[Roman Catholic Church]], but "flunk[ed] the period of inquiry"; he later attended a [[Mennonite]] church.{{cite web|url=https://www.themonthly.com.au/issue/2008/november/1277253270/malcolm-knox/everything-more|title=Everything & More: The Work of David Foster Wallace|first=Malcolm |last=Knox |authorlink=Malcolm Knox (author) |date=November 2008|work=[[The Monthly]]}}{{cite web|url=http://patrickarden.com/DavidFosterWallace.html|title=David Foster Wallace warms up|first=Patrick |last=Arden|work=[[Book (magazine)|Book]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mbird.com/2012/08/david-foster-wallace-went-to-church-constantly/|title=David Foster Wallace Went to Church Constantly?|first=David |last=Zahl|date=August 20, 2012|work=Mockingbird}} Wallace attended [[Amherst College]], his father's alma mater, where he majored in English and philosophy, and graduated ''[[summa cum laude]]'' in 1985. Among other extracurricular activities, he participated in [[glee club]]; his sister recalls that "David had a lovely singing voice". In studying philosophy, Wallace pursued [[modal logic]] and mathematics, and presented a senior thesis in philosophy and modal logic{{cite news| title = Consider the Philosopher| work=[[The New York Times]] |last=Ryerson |first=James |date=December 12, 2008 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/12/14/magazine/14wwln-Wallace-t.html?_r=2&ref=magazine | accessdate=April 2, 2010}} that was awarded the Gail Kennedy Memorial Prize and posthumously published as ''Fate, Time, and Language: An Essay on Free Will'' (2011).{{cite web|url=https://cms.amherst.edu/academiclife/departments/philosophy/alumni |title=Our Alumni, Amherst College |publisher=[[Amherst College]] |date=November 17, 2007 |accessdate=February 26, 2011}} By the time he graduated, with his honors thesis in English becoming the manuscript of his first novel, ''[[The Broom of the System]]'' (1987),{{cite web|url=https://www.amherst.edu/aboutamherst/news/memoriam/node/65728 |title=In Memoriam: David Foster Wallace '85, Amherst College |publisher=[[Amherst College]] |date=September 14, 2008 |accessdate=February 26, 2011}} Wallace had committed himself to being a writer. He told [[David Lipsky]]: "Writing [''The Broom of the System''], I felt like I was using ninety-seven percent of me, whereas philosophy was using fifty percent." Wallace completed a [[Master of Fine Arts]] degree in creative writing at the University of Arizona in 1987. He then moved to Massachusetts to attend graduate school in philosophy at Harvard University, but soon left the program. Wallace's biographer [[D.T. Max]] wrote in ''Every Love Story Is a Ghost Story: A Life of David Foster Wallace'' (2012), of Wallace's romantic obsession with the writer [[Mary Karr]] in the early 1990s, which resulted in his tattooing her name on his body.{{cite journal |last=Hughes |first=Evan |date=October 9, 2011 |url=http://nymag.com/arts/books/features/jeffrey-eugenides-2011-10/ |title=Just Kids Jeffrey Eugenides insists his new novel is not a roman à clef |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]}} He also considered killing her husband. Wallace and Karr later had a tumultuous relationship, during which, Karr has said, Wallace once threw a coffee table at her, and another time tried to push her out of a moving car. In 2002, Wallace met the painter [[Karen L. Green]], whom he married on December 27, 2004.{{cite web|last1=Williams|first1=John|title=God, Mary Karr and Ronald Reagan: D.T. Max on David Foster Wallace|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/09/12/god-mary-karr-and-ronald-reagan-d-t-max-on-david-foster-wallace/?_r=0|website=New York Times Arts Beat blog|date=September 12, 2012}}{{cite news| title = David Foster Wallace, Influential Writer, Dies at 46| work=[[The New York Times]]|first= Bruce |last=Weber | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/15/books/15wallace.html?em| date=September 14, 2008| accessdate=April 2, 2010}}{{cite web| title = The Lost Years & Last Days of David Foster Wallace | work = [[Rolling Stone]]|last = Lipsky |first=Dave |date = October 30, 2008 | url = https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/23638511/the_lost_years__last_days_of_david_foster_wallace | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090503103755/http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/23638511/the_lost_years__last_days_of_david_foster_wallace| archivedate = May 3, 2009| accessdate = April 2, 2012}} Wallace struggled with depression, alcoholism, drug addiction, and suicidal tendencies, with recurrent psychiatric hospitalizations. He stalked a woman of whom he was enamored.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/779263461|title=Every Love Story Is a Ghost Story: A Life of David Foster Wallace|last=Max|first=Daniel (D.T.)|date=2012|publisher=Viking|year=|isbn=9780670025923|location=New York|pages=|oclc=779263461}} Dogs were important to him,{{cite web| title = The Unfinished| work=[[The New Yorker]] |first= D. T. |last=Max |date= March 9, 2009 | url = http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2009/03/09/090309fa_fact_max?currentPage=all}} and he spoke of opening a shelter for stray canines. According to his friend [[Jonathan Franzen]], Wallace "had a predilection for dogs who'd been abused, and [were] unlikely to find other owners who were going to be patient enough for them." ==Work== ===Career=== ''[[The Broom of the System]]'' (1987) garnered national attention and critical praise. In ''The New York Times'', the reviewer [[Caryn James]] called the novel a "manic, human, flawed extravaganza … emerging straight from the excessive tradition of [[Stanley Elkin]]'s ''The Franchiser'', [[Thomas Pynchon]]'s ''[[V.]]'', [and] [[John Irving]]'s ''[[The World According to Garp|World According to Garp]]''".{{cite news|last1=James|first1=Caryn |authorlink1=Caryn James |title=Wittgenstein Is Dead and Living in Ohio – The Broom of the System,|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/97/03/16/reviews/wallace-r-broom.html|accessdate=March 23, 2017|work=[[The New York Times]] |date=March 1, 1987}} In 1991, Wallace began teaching literature as an adjunct professor at [[Emerson College]] in Boston. The next year, at the suggestion of colleague and supporter [[Steven Moore (US author)|Steven Moore]], Wallace obtained a position in the [[English studies|English]] department at [[Illinois State University]]. He had begun work on his second novel, ''[[Infinite Jest]]'', in 1991, and submitted a draft to his editor in December 1993. After the publication of excerpts throughout 1995, the book was published in 1996. In 1997, Wallace received a [[MacArthur Fellowship]], as well as the [[Aga Khan Prize for Fiction]], awarded by editors of ''[[The Paris Review]]'' for one of the stories in ''Brief Interviews'' which had appeared in the magazine.{{cite journal|last1=Wallace|first1=David Foster|title=Brief Interviews with Hideous Men|journal=[[The Paris Review]]|date=Fall 1997|issue=144|url=https://www.theparisreview.org/fiction/1225/brief-interviews-with-hideous-men-david-foster-wallace|accessdate=23 March 2017}} In 2002, he moved to [[Claremont, California]], to become the first [[Roy E. Disney]] Professor of Creative Writing and Professor of English at [[Pomona College]]. He taught one or two undergraduate courses per semester and focused on writing. Wallace delivered the commencement address to the 2005 graduating class at [[Kenyon College]]. The speech was published as a book, ''[[This Is Water]]'', in 2009.{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/26/books/review/Bissell-t.html | title = Great and Terrible Truths | accessdate =December 8, 2010 | work=The New York Times | first=Tom | last=Bissell |authorlink= Tom Bissell | date=April 26, 2009}} In May 2013, parts of the speech were used in a popular online video, also titled "This Is Water".{{cite news | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/william-mcguinness/david-foster-wallaces-bri_b_3239411.html | title = David Foster Wallace's Brilliant 'This Is Water' Commencement Address Is Now a Great Short Film | accessdate =May 9, 2013 | work=[[The Huffington Post]] | first=William | last=McGuinness | date=May 8, 2013}} Bonnie Nadell was Wallace's literary agent during his entire career.{{cite web | title = Remembering David Foster Wallace: 'David Would Never Stop Caring' Says Lifelong Agent| publisher=''Bay Ledger News Zone'' |last=Neyfakh |first=Leon |authorlink= Leon Neyfakh |date=September 17, 2008 | url = http://www.blnz.com/news/2008/09/17/Remembering_David_Foster_Wallace_David_1209.html}} Michael Pietsch was his editor on ''Infinite Jest''.{{cite web | title = Infinite Jest Editor Michael Pietsch of Little, Brown on David Foster Wallace | work=[[The New York Observer]] |last=Neyfakh |first=Leon |authorlink= Leon Neyfakh |date=September 19, 2008| url = http://www.observer.com/2008/media/little-brown-publisher-michael-pietsch-his-writer-david-foster-wallace}} In March 2009, [[Little, Brown and Company]] announced that it would publish the manuscript of an unfinished novel, ''[[The Pale King]]'', which Wallace had been working on before his death. ''The Pale King'' was pieced together by Pietsch from pages and notes Wallace left behind.{{cite news| title = Maximized Revenue, Minimized Existence| first = Michiko |last=Kakutani |authorlink= Michiko Kakutani |work=[[The New York Times]]| date = March 31, 2011| accessdate = April 2, 2012 |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/01/books/the-pale-king-by-david-foster-wallace-book-review.html }}{{cite news|title = Unfinished novel by Wallace coming next year| agency = Associated Press|work=USA Today|date = March 1, 2009| accessdate = April 2, 2012| url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/books/news/2009-03-01-wallace-novel_N.htm }} [[The Pale King#Published excerpts|Several excerpts]] were published in ''[[The New Yorker]]'' and other magazines. ''The Pale King'' was published on April 15, 2011, and received generally positive reviews.{{cite web |title = David Foster Wallace's ''The Pale King'' Gets Thoughtful, Glowing Reviews| author = Willa Paskin|work =[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|date = April 5, 2011|url=http://www.vulture.com/2011/04/david_foster_wallace.html|accessdate=April 2, 2012}} It was also nominated for the Pulitzer Prize.{{cite web |url=http://www.pulitzer.org/prize-winners-by-category/219 |title=Fiction |publisher=[[The Pulitzer Prizes]]}} Throughout his career, Wallace published short fiction in periodicals such as ''[[The New Yorker]]'', ''[[GQ (magazine)|GQ]]'', ''[[Harper's Magazine]]'', ''[[Playboy]]'', ''[[The Paris Review]]'', ''[[Mid-American Review]]'', ''[[Conjunctions]]'', ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'', ''[[Open City (magazine)|Open City]]'', ''[[Puerto del Sol]]'', and ''[[Timothy McSweeney's Quarterly Concern]]''. ===Themes and styles=== Wallace wanted to progress beyond the [[irony]] and [[metafiction]] associated with [[postmodernism]]; in the essay "E Unibus Pluram: Television and U.S. Fiction" (1993),{{Cite journal|last=Wallace|first=David Foster|title=E Unibus Pluram: Television and U.S. Fiction|journal=Review of Contemporary Fiction|volume=13|issue=2|pages=151–194}} he proposed that television has an ironic influence on fiction, and urges literary authors to eschew TV's shallow rebelliousness: "I want to convince you that irony, poker-faced silence, and fear of ridicule are distinctive of those features of contemporary U.S. culture (of which cutting-edge fiction is a part) that enjoy any significant relation to the television whose weird, pretty hand has my generation by the throat. I'm going to argue that irony and ridicule are entertaining and effective, and that, at the same time, they are agents of a great despair and stasis in U.S. culture, and that, for aspiring fictionists, they pose terrifically vexing problems." Wallace used many forms of irony, but tended to focus on individual persons' continued longing for earnest, un-self-conscious experience and communication in a media-saturated society.{{cite web |url=http://rci.rutgers.edu/%7Ewcd/jestcomp.htm |title=A Reader's Companion to Infinite Jest |first=William C. |last=Dowling |authorlink=William C. Dowling |publisher=[[Rutgers University]] |accessdate=February 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110412061813/http://www.rci.rutgers.edu/~wcd/jestcomp.htm |archivedate=April 12, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} Wallace's fiction combines narrative modes and authorial voices that incorporate jargon and invented vocabulary, such as self-generated abbreviations and acronyms, long, multi-[[clause]] sentences, and an extensive use of explanatory [[Note (typography)|endnotes]] and footnotes, as in ''Infinite Jest'' and the story "Octet" (collected in ''[[Brief Interviews with Hideous Men]]'') and most of his non-fiction after 1996. In a 1997 interview on ''[[Charlie Rose (TV series)|Charlie Rose]]'', Wallace said that the notes were to disrupt the linear narrative, to reflect his perception of reality without jumbling the narrative structure, and that he could have jumbled the sentences "but then no one would read it".{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mLPStHVi0SI |title=Charlie Rose – Jennifer Harbury & Robert Torricelli / David Foster Wallace |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=February 26, 2011}} Max has described Wallace's work as an "unusual mixture of the cerebral and the hot-blooded",{{cite web|url=http://untitledbooks.com/features/features/a-meaningful-life-by-dt-max/|title=A Meaningful Life|first=D. T. |last=Max|work=Untitled Books|issue=50|date=December 2012|publisher=|accessdate=September 21, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150217050118/http://untitledbooks.com/features/features/a-meaningful-life-by-dt-max/|archivedate=February 17, 2015|df=mdy-all}} often featuring multiple protagonists and spanning different locations in a single work. His writing comments on the fragmentation of thought,{{cite web|url=http://www.thehowlingfantods.com/iaminhere.htm|title="I Am in Here": Fragmentation and the Individual in David Foster Wallace's Infinite Jest|first1=Travis W. |last1=Stern |first2=Robert L. |last2=McLaughlin|date=Spring 2000|publisher=The Howling Fantods |accessdate=September 21, 2014}} the relationship between happiness and boredom, and the psychological tension between the beauty and hideousness of the human body.{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/culturebox/2011/04/infinite_attention.html|first=Matt|last=Feeney|title=Infinite Attention – David Foster Wallace and being bored out of your mind|date=April 12, 2011|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|accessdate=September 21, 2014}} According to Wallace, "fiction's about what it is to be a fucking human being", and he said he wanted to write "morally passionate, passionately moral fiction" that could help the reader "become less alone inside".{{cite web|first=D. T. |last=Max |url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2009/03/09/090309fa_fact_max |title=David Foster Wallace's Struggle to Surpass ''Infinite Jest'' |work=[[The New Yorker]] |date=January 7, 2009 |accessdate=February 26, 2011}} In his Kenyon College commencement address, Wallace described the human condition as daily crises and chronic disillusionment and warned against succumbing to [[solipsism]],{{cite web |last=Krajeski |first=Jenna |url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/books/2008/09/this-is-water.html |title=This is Water |work=[[The New Yorker]] |date=September 22, 2008}} invoking the existential values of compassion and mindfulness: {{quote|The really important kind of freedom involves attention, and awareness, and discipline, and effort, and being able truly to care about other people and to sacrifice for them, over and over, in myriad petty little unsexy ways, every day. . . . The only thing that's capital-T True is that you get to decide how you're going to try to see it. You get to consciously decide what has meaning and what doesn't. . . . The trick is keeping the truth up-front in daily consciousness.{{Cite news| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB122178211966454607 | work=The Wall Street Journal | title=David Foster Wallace on Life and Work | date=September 19, 2008}}}} ===Nonfiction=== Wallace covered Senator [[John McCain's 2000 presidential campaign]]{{cite web| title = The Weasel, Twelve Monkeys and The Shrub| author = Wallace, David Foster| work=[[Rolling Stone]]| date = April 13, 2000| url = https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/story/18420304/the_weasel_twelve_monkeys_and_the_shrub/1| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090519105330/http://www.rollingstone.com/politics/story/18420304/the_weasel_twelve_monkeys_and_the_shrub/1| archivedate = May 19, 2009| accessdate = April 2, 2012}} "The Weasel, Twelve Monkeys and The Shrub" was [[parody|parodied]] in the Salon.com article [http://www.salon.com/2000/04/04/wallace_6/ "David Foster Wallace: Ain't McCain Grand"]. and the [[September 11 attacks]] for ''[[Rolling Stone]]'';{{cite journal| author = Wallace, David Foster | date = October 25, 2001| title =9/11: The View From the Midwest| journal =[[Rolling Stone]] | issue = 880|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/news/9-11-the-view-from-the-midwest-20110819}} cruise ships{{cite news |author = Wallace, David Foster | title = Shipping Out | url = http://harpers.org/archive/1996/01/shipping-out/| format= PDF |newspaper= [[Harper's Magazine]] |date = January 1996}} (in what became the title essay of his first nonfiction book), [[state fairs]], and [[tornadoes]] for ''[[Harper's Magazine]]''; the [[US Open (tennis)|US Open]] tournament for ''[[Tennis (magazine)|Tennis]]'' magazine; the director [[David Lynch]] and the [[pornography industry]] for ''[[Premiere (magazine)|Premiere]]'' magazine; the [[tennis]] player [[Michael Joyce (tennis)|Michael Joyce]] for ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]''; the movie-special-effects industry for ''[[Waterstone's]]'' magazine; conservative talk radio host [[John Ziegler (talk show host)|John Ziegler]] for ''[[The Atlantic]]'';{{cite journal |last=Wallace |first=David Foster |date=April 2005 |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/doc/200504/wallace |title=Host |work=[[The Atlantic Monthly]]}} and a [[Maine]] lobster festival for ''[[Gourmet (magazine)|Gourmet]]'' magazine.{{Cite magazine|last=Wallace|first=David Foster|date=August 2004|title=Consider the Lobster|url=http://www.columbia.edu/~col8/lobsterarticle.pdf|magazine=[[Gourmet (magazine)|Gourmet]]|pages=50–64}} He also reviewed books in several genres for the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'', ''[[The New York Times]]'', and ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]''. In the November 2007 issue of ''The Atlantic'', which commemorated the magazine's 150th anniversary, Wallace was among the authors, artists, politicians and others who wrote short pieces on "the future of the American idea".{{cite book|last1=Hoffmann|first1=Lukas|title=Postirony: The Nonfictional Literature of David Foster Wallace and Dave Eggers|date=2016|publisher=transcript|location=Bielefeld|isbn=978-3-8376-3661-1}} These and other essays appear in three collections, ''[[A Supposedly Fun Thing I'll Never Do Again]], [[Consider the Lobster]],'' and the posthumous ''[[Both Flesh and Not]],'' the last of which contains some of Wallace's earliest work, including his first published essay, "Fictional Futures and the Conspicuously Young".{{Cite news|url = http://www.newyorker.com/books/page-turner/d-f-w-s-nonfiction-better-with-age|title = D.F.W.'s Nonfiction: Better with Age|last = Max|first = D. T.|date = 2012-11-14|newspaper = [[The New Yorker]] |issn = 0028-792X|access-date = 2016-02-21}} Some writers have found parts of Wallace's nonfiction implausible. Franzen has said that he believes Wallace made up dialogue and incidents: "those things didn't actually happen".{{cite web|last=Dean|first=Michelle |authorlink= Michelle Dean |title=A Supposedly True Thing Jonathan Franzen Said About David Foster Wallace|url=https://theawl.com/a-supposedly-true-thing-jonathan-franzen-said-about-david-foster-wallace-8f37fd7c0bfd#.t1qt4lyho|website=[[The Awl]]|accessdate=25 December 2016}} [[John Cook (reporter)|John Cook]] has remarked that "Wallace encounters pitch-perfect characters who speak comedically crystalline lines and place him in hilariously absurd situations...I used both stories ''[in teaching journalism]'' as examples of the inescapable temptation to shave, embellish, and invent narratives".{{cite web|last1=Cook|first1=John|title=There Is No Such Thing as a 'Larger Truth': This American Life's Rich History of Embellishment|url=http://gawker.com/5894913/there-is-no-such-thing-as-a-larger-truth-this-american-lifes-rich-history-of-embellishment|website=[[Gawker]]|accessdate=25 December 2016}} == Legacy == In March 2010, the media announced that Wallace's personal papers and archives—drafts of books, stories, essays, poems, letters, and research, including the handwritten notes for ''[[Infinite Jest]]''—had been purchased by the [[University of Texas at Austin]], and they now reside at that university's [[Harry Ransom Center]].{{Cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/09/books/09arts-DAVIDFOSTERW_BRF.html | work=The New York Times | title=David Foster Wallace Papers Are Bought | first=Patricia | last=Cohen | date=March 9, 2010 | accessdate=April 2, 2010}} The first annual David Foster Wallace Conference was hosted by the [[Illinois State University]] Department of English in May 2014; the second was held in May 2015.{{cite web|url=https://faculty.sharepoint.illinoisstate.edu/dfw/Pages/Conference-Program.aspx|title=David Foster Wallace Conference Program 2015 |publisher=[[Illinois State University]]| accessdate=July 23, 2015}} Since 2011, [[Loyola University New Orleans]] has offered English seminar courses on Wallace. Similar courses are also taught at [[Harvard University]]. In January 2017, the International David Foster Wallace Society and the ''Journal of David Foster Wallace Studies'' were launched.[https://www.dfwsociety.org/ The International David Foster Wallace Society.] ===Adaptations=== ====Film and television==== A [[Brief Interviews with Hideous Men (film)|feature-length film adaptation]] of ''Brief Interviews with Hideous Men'', directed by [[John Krasinski]] with an ensemble cast, was released in 2009 and premiered at the [[Sundance Film Festival]].{{cite news| title = John Krasinski, 'Brief Interviews With Hideous Men'| author = Lee, Chris| url = http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-et-krasinski19-2009jan19,0,364630.story|work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date = January 19, 2009| accessdate = April 2, 2012}} It received poor reviews. The 19th episode of the 23rd season of ''[[The Simpsons]]'', "[[A Totally Fun Thing That Bart Will Never Do Again]]" (2012), is loosely based on Wallace's essay "[[A Supposedly Fun Thing I'll Never Do Again]]". The Simpson family takes a cruise, and Wallace appears in the background of a scene, wearing a tuxedo T-shirt while eating in the ship's dining room; Wallace recounted having worn such a T-shirt "at formal suppers".{{Quote without source|date=June 2018}} The 2015 film ''[[The End of the Tour (2015 film)|The End of the Tour]]'' is based on conversations [[David Lipsky]] had with Wallace, transcribed in ''[[Although of Course You End Up Becoming Yourself]]'' (2010). [[Jason Segel]] played Wallace, and [[Jesse Eisenberg]] Lipsky. The film won an Audience Award for Best Narrative Feature at the [[Sarasota Film Festival]],{{cite news|title=2015 Sarasota Film Festival Awards|url=http://www.bradenton.com/2015/04/19/5753400/2015-sarasota-film-festival-awards.html|accessdate=11 September 2015|work=[[Bradenton Herald]]|date=19 April 2015}} and Segel was nominated for the [[Independent Spirit Award for Best Male Lead]]. "Partridge", a Season 5 episode of [[NBC]]'s ''[[Parks and Recreation]]'', repeatedly references ''Infinite Jest'', of which the show's co-creator, [[Michael Schur]], is a noted fan. Schur also directed the music video for [[The Decemberists]]' "Calamity Song", which depicts the Eschaton game from ''Infinite Jest.''{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xJpfK7l404I|title=The Decemberists - Calamity Song|date=August 16, 2011|work=YouTube}} ==== Stage and music ==== Twelve of the interviews from ''Brief Interviews with Hideous Men'' were adapted into a stage play in 2000, the first theatrical adaptation of Wallace's work. The play, ''Hideous Men'', adapted and directed by Dylan McCullough, premiered at the [[New York International Fringe Festival]] in August 2000. ''Brief Interviews'' was also adapted by director Marc Caellas as a play, ''Brief Interviews with Hideous Writers'', which premiered at Fundación Tomás Eloy Martinez in [[Buenos Aires]] on November 4, 2011.{{cite news |first=Andrés |last=Hax |url=http://www.revistaenie.clarin.com/escenarios/teatro/Entrevistas_breves_con_escritores_repulsivos-Fundacion_TEM_0_583141891.html|title=Entrevistas repulsivas en la Fundación Tomás Eloy Martínez |date=November 1, 2011 |work=[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315141724/http://www.revistaenie.clarin.com/escenarios/teatro/Entrevistas_breves_con_escritores_repulsivos-Fundacion_TEM_0_583141891.html |archivedate=March 15, 2016 |language=es}} The short story "Tri-Stan: I Sold Sissee Nar to Ecko" from ''Brief Interviews with Hideous Men'' was adapted by composer [[Eric Moe (composer)|Eric Moe]]{{cite web|url=http://fictionwritersreview.com/essays/dfw-me-an-arranged-marriage-of-music-and-fiction |title=DFW + Me = An 'Arranged' Marriage of Music and Fiction |work=[[Fiction Writers Review]] |first=Eric |last=Moe |authorlink=Eric Moe (composer) |date=October 19, 2011|accessdate=October 19, 2011}} into a 50-minute operatic piece, to be performed with accompanying video projections.{{cite web|url=http://www.ericmoe.net/tristan.html |title=Tri-Stan |publisher=ericmoe.net|first=Eric |last=Moe |authorlink=Eric Moe (composer) |accessdate=February 26, 2011}} The piece was described as having "subversively inscribed classical music into pop culture".{{Cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/02/arts/music/02sequ.html | work=[[The New York Times]] | title=A Menu of Familiar Signposts and a One-Woman Opera | first=Anne | last=Midgette |authorlink=Anne Midgette| date=April 2, 2005 | accessdate=April 2, 2010}} ''Infinite Jest'' was performed once as a stage play by Germany's experimental theater [[Hebbel am Ufer]]. The play was staged in various locations throughout [[Berlin]], and the action took place over a 24-hour period.{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/culturebox/2012/06/infinite_jest_on_stage_berlin_theater_adaptation_of_david_foster_wallace_s_novel_.html|author=Wiener, Aaron|title=Infinite Jest! Live! On Stage! One Entire Day Only! |date=June 18, 2012|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|accessdate=September 21, 2014}} "Good Old Neon", from ''[[Oblivion: Stories]]'', was adapted and performed by Ian Forester at the 2011 [[Hollywood Fringe Festival]], produced by the Los Angeles independent theater company Needtheater.{{cite web|url=http://laist.com/2011/06/17/hollywood_fringe_festival_2011_deit.php|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171105200702/http://laist.com/2011/06/17/hollywood_fringe_festival_2011_deit.php|dead-url=yes|archive-date=November 5, 2017|title="Hollywood Fringe Festival 2011: 'Deity Clutch,' 'Dumb Waiter,' 'Glint'", LAist.|work=LAist|accessdate=September 21, 2014}} The song "Surrounded by Heads and Bodies" from the album [[A Brief Inquiry into Online Relationships|''A Brief Inquiry into Online Relationships'']] by [[The 1975]], borrows its title from the opening line of ''Infinite Jest''.https://pitchfork.com/features/song-by-song/the-1975s-matty-healy-dissects-every-song-on-a-brief-inquiry-into-online-relationships/ [[Matty Healy]], he lead singer of The 1975, revealed in a interview with Pitchfork discussing the new album that he was inspired by the novel after reading it during a stint in rehab: "I was reading [''Infinite Jest''] when I was in rehab. There was no one there. It was me and my nurses, who’d come in and check on me, and then Angela [the protagonist of the song], miles away. I was surrounded by no one, and the book was just open on the front page, as most copies of ''Infinite Jest'' are ..... nobody reads [''Infinite Jest''] all the way! Everyone our age has got a battered, quarter-read copy of ''Infinite Jest''."https://pitchfork.com/features/song-by-song/the-1975s-matty-healy-dissects-every-song-on-a-brief-inquiry-into-online-relationships/ ==Death== Wallace's father said that David had suffered from [[major depressive disorder]] for more than 20 years and that [[antidepressant]] medication had allowed him to be productive. Wallace experienced severe side effects from the medication and in June 2007 stopped taking [[phenelzine]], his primary antidepressant drug, on his doctor's advice. His depression recurred, and he tried other treatments, including [[electroconvulsive therapy]]. Eventually he went back on phenelzine but found it ineffective. On September 12, 2008, at age 46, Wallace wrote a two-page suicide note, arranged part of the manuscript for ''[[The Pale King]]'' and hanged himself from a rafter of his house.{{cite book |first=D. T. |last=Max |title=Every Love Story Is a Ghost Story: A Life of David Foster Wallace |page=301 |isbn=978 1 84708 494 1}}. Memorial gatherings were held at Pomona College, Amherst College, the University of Arizona, Illinois State University, and on October 23, 2008, at New York University (NYU). The eulogists at NYU included his sister, Amy Wallace-Havens; his literary agent, Bonnie Nadell; [[Gerry Howard]], editor of his first two books; [[Colin Harrison (writer)|Colin Harrison]], an editor at ''Harper's Magazine''; Michael Pietsch, editor of ''Infinite Jest'' and later works; Deborah Treisman, fiction editor at ''The New Yorker'' magazine; and the writers [[Don DeLillo]], [[Zadie Smith]], [[George Saunders]], Mark Costello, [[Donald Antrim]], and Jonathan Franzen.{{cite web| title = Jonathan Franzen Remembers David Foster Wallace |work=[[New York Observer]]|first= Adam|last= Begley |authorlink= Adam Begley | date=October 27, 2008 | url = http://observer.com/2008/10/our-critics-tip-sheet-on-current-reading-jonathan-franzen-remembers-david-foster-wallace-mencken-disses-joe-sixpack/}}{{cite web|url=http://fivedials.com/files/fivedials_no10.pdf|title=Celebrating the Life and Work of David Foster Wallace|work=[[Five Dials]]|publisher=[[Hamish Hamilton]]|accessdate=May 11, 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/24/books/24wallace.html?_r=0|title=Remembering Writer of 'Infinite Jest'|last=Konigsberg|first=Eric|date=October 24, 2008|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=May 11, 2013}} ==Bibliography== {{main|David Foster Wallace bibliography}} ==Awards and honors== * [[Pulitzer Prize for Fiction|Pulitzer Prize]] nomination for ''[[The Pale King]]'', 2012 * Inclusion of "Good Old Neon" in ''[[O. Henry Award|The O. Henry Prize]] Stories 2002'' * John D. and Catherine T.
