{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2014}} [[File:Ivan-Medek.jpg|thumb|Ivan Medek, Czech journalist, classical music critic, radio broadcaster, signatory of Charta 77]] '''Ivan Medek''' (July 13, 1925 – January 6, 2010) was a Czech classical music critic, radio broadcaster and journalist. Medek was an important voice of the Czech [[anti-communist]] opposition movement, particularly after being forced into [[exile]] from [[Czechoslovakia]] in 1978.<ref name=nyt>{{cite news |first=|last=|title=Former Czech Chancellor Ivan Medek Dies at 84 |url=http://seattletimes.com/html/nationworld/2010713861_apeuczechobitmedek.html|work=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=[[The Seattle Times]] |date=January 6, 2010 |accessdate=2013-12-10}}</ref><ref name=radiopraha>{{cite news |first=Chris |last=Johnstone |title=Legendary Czech broadcaster Ivan Medek remembered |url=http://www.radio.cz/en/article/123819 |work=[[Radio Praha]] |publisher= |date=January 7, 2010 |accessdate=2010-01-07}}</ref> Medek collaborated closely with such Czechoslovak politicians as [[Václav Havel]] and [[Pavel Tigrid]] in opposition to communist rule.<ref name=nyt/><ref name=radiopraha/>
Medek was born in [[Prague]], [[Czechoslovakia]], on July 13, 1925.<ref name=nyt/> He began his career as both a classical music critic and journalist.<ref name=nyt/> He worked as a musician for the [[Czech Philharmonic]] until he was fired by the government for his support of the opposition.<ref name=radiopraha/>
Medek was an original signatory of the [[Charter 77]] [[manifesto]] in 1977.<ref name=nyt/> Persecution by the communist government for his participation in Charter 77 forced Medek into [[exile]] in neighboring [[Austria]] beginning in 1978.<ref name=nyt/> Medek began working at the [[Voice of America]] in Austria, where he broadcast [[news]] and information into [[Czechoslovakia]].<ref name=nyt/> His VoA radio broadcasts became an important link for anti-communist [[dissidents]] in his native Czechoslovakia.<ref name=radiopraha/>
Medek returned to Czechoslovakia from exile in 1989 during the [[Velvet Revolution]].<ref name=radiopraha/> In 1993, Medek was appointed to the office of the presidency under [[Václav Havel]], the first president of the [[Czech Republic]].<ref name=radiopraha/> He later became the head of the presidency, or chancellor, under Havel.<ref name=nyt/><ref name=radiopraha/>
Medek died in [[Prague]] on January 6, 2010, at the age of 84. He was survived by his wife, Helena.<ref name=nyt/>

[[University of Maribor]] | signature = Janez Drnovšek signature.png }} '''Janez Drnovšek''' ({{IPA-sl|ˈjàːnɛz dəɾˈnɔ́ːwʃək}};{{cite web|title=Slovenski pravopis 2001: Janez|url=http://bos.zrc-sazu.si/c/SP/neva.exe?name=sp&expression=Janez&hs=1}} {{cite web|title=Slovenski pravopis 2001: Drnovšek|url=http://bos.zrc-sazu.si/c/SP/neva.exe?name=sp&expression=Drnov%C5%A1ek&hs=1}}''Janez'' in isolation: {{IPA-sl|ˈjàːnɛs|}}. 17 May 1950 – 23 February 2008) was a [[Slovenia]]n [[liberalism|liberal]] [[politician]], [[President of the Presidency of Yugoslavia]] (1989–1990), [[Prime Minister of Slovenia]] (1992–2002) and [[President of Slovenia]] (2002–2007). ==Youth and early career== {{unsourced|section|date=May 2018}} Drnovšek was born in [[Celje]] and was raised in the small town of [[Kisovec]] in the Municipality of [[Zagorje ob Savi]], where his father Viktor was the local mine chief and his mother Silva was a homemaker. Drnovšek graduated from the [[University of Ljubljana]] with a degree in economics in 1973. Meanwhile, he worked as an intern at a [[Le Havre]] bank. In 1975, at the age of 25, he became chief financial officer at SGP Beton Zagorje, a construction company. Two years later he became, for one year, an economic adviser at the [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] [[embassy]] in [[Cairo]]. He defended his master's thesis in 1981, and in 1986, he defended his dissertation in 1986 at the Faculty of Economics and Business at the [[University of Maribor]]. In 1982, he became head of the local branch of Ljubljana Bank in his home region of the [[Central Sava Valley]] in central Slovenia. In 1986 he was chosen to be a delegate at the Slovenian Republic Assembly (parliament) and also the Chamber of Republics and Provinces of the Yugoslav parliament. ==Membership in the Yugoslav presidency== {{unsourced|section|date=May 2018}} In 1989, [[Stane Dolanc]], the [[Socialist Republic of Slovenia|Slovenia]]n representative to the collective presidency of Yugoslavia, retired. The Slovenian [[Communist Party of Slovenia|Communist Party]], aware of upcoming democratisation, decided to organize elections between two candidates for the position. Drnovšek, until then rather unknown to the public, defeated [[:sl:Marko Bulc|Marko Bulc]], the Party's preferred candidate. The Communist leaderships of other Yugoslav republics did not agree with this new way of selecting the representative to the Collective Presidency, so the Slovenian Republic Parliament had to confirm the result of the elections. Drnovšek served as chairman of the Collective Presidency from 1989-90. While he was chairman of the presidency, he was also chairman of the [[Non-Aligned Movement]] and the commander of the [[Yugoslav People's Army]]. Until the end of communist rule he was an active member of the Communist Party. After the democratic changes in Slovenia, the country seceded from Yugoslavia. Following the [[Ten Day War]], Drnovšek used his position in the Collective Presidency to help mediate the [[Brioni Agreement]] and to negotiate a peaceful withdrawal of [[Yugoslav People's Army|Yugoslav army]] from Slovenia. ==Prime Minister of Slovenia== {{onesource|section|date=May 2018}} In 1992, after a Government crisis in the [[DEMOS coalition]], which had won the first democratic elections in Slovenia in 1990 and led the country to independence, Drnovšek became the second [[Prime Minister]] of independent Slovenia. He was chosen as a compromise candidate and an expert in economic policy. His bi-partisan government was supported both by the left and centrist wing of the dissolved [[DEMOS coalition]] (the [[Social Democratic Party of Slovenia]], the [[Democratic Party (Slovenia)|Democratic Party]] and the [[Greens of Slovenia]]) and by three parties that derived from organizations of the former Communist regime (the [[Liberal Democratic Party (Slovenia)|Liberal Democratic Party]], the [[Social Democrats (Slovenia)|Party of Democratic Reform]] and the [[Socialist Party of Slovenia]]). Shortly afterwards, Drnovšek was elected president of the [[Liberal Democratic Party (Slovenia)|Liberal Democratic Party]] (''Liberalno demokratska stranka'' – LDS), the legal successor of the Association of Socialist Youth of Slovenia (''Zveza socialistične mladine Slovenije'' – ZSMS), the youth fraction of the [[Communist Party of Slovenia]]. In 1992, the Liberal Democratic Party under Drnovšek's leadership won the parliamentary elections, but due to a high fragmentation of the popular vote had to ally itself with other parties in order to form a stable government. Despite a politically turbulent mandate (in 1994, the [[Social Democratic Party of Slovenia]] left the coalition), the Party gained votes in 1996, remaining the largest party in the government. Nevertheless, Drnovšek barely secured himself a third term in office after a failed attempt to ally himself with the [[Slovenian National Party]]. In 1997, the [[Liberal Democracy of Slovenia]] formed a coalition government with the populist [[Slovenian People's Party]] which finally enabled Drnovšek to serve a third term in office. He headed the government until May 2000, when he stepped down due to disagreements with the [[Slovenian People's Party]]. After less than six months in opposition, Drnovšek returned to power in the autumn of 2000, after his party gained a clear victory in the parliamentary elections. Drnovšek's governments guided Slovenia's political and [[economic reconstruction]]. He successfully tackled the twin tasks of reorienting Slovenia's trade away from the wreckage of the old Yugoslavia towards the West and replacing the ineffective Communist-era business model with more market-based mechanisms. Unlike the other five former Yugoslav republics which were run for much of the 1990s by frequently authoritarian presidents, Slovenia under Drnovšek's premiership quickly emerged from the break-up of the federation as a functioning [[parliamentary democracy]]. Drnovšek's political strategy was concentrated on broad coalitions, transcending ideological and programmatic divisions between parties. [[File:Vladimir Putin 24 March 2001-1.jpg|thumb|Drnovšek with [[Vladimir Putin]] in 2001]] Contrary to some other former Communist countries in [[Eastern Europe]], the economic and social transformation in Slovenia pursued by Drnovšek's governments followed a [[gradualist]] approach.[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/janez-drnovsek-slovenian-president-who-achieved-membership-of-the-eu-and-nato-for-the-former-yugoslav-republic-786789.html "Janez Drnovsek: Slovenian president who achieved membership of the EU and Nato for the former Yugoslav republic"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705211518/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/janez-drnovsek-slovenian-president-who-achieved-membership-of-the-eu-and-nato-for-the-former-yugoslav-republic-786789.html|date=5 July 2015|publisher=independent.co.uk}} Drnovšek was a staunch supporter of Slovenia's entry in the [[European Union]] and [[NATO]] and was largely responsible for Slovenia's successful bid for membership in both of those organizations. As Prime minister, he was frequently active on foreign policy issues. On 16 June 2001, he helped to arrange the first meeting of the U.S. President [[George W. Bush]] with the Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]], which was held in the [[Upper Carniola]]n estate of [[Brdo pri Kranju]]. ([[Bush-Putin 2001]]) In 2002, he ran for [[President of Slovenia]], and was elected in the second round, defeating the center-right candidate [[Barbara Brezigar]]. ==President of Slovenia and the change in lifestyle== Drnovšek's presidency was highly controversial. In the first three years in office, he rarely appeared in public, save for the most important official duties. In 2006, however, a change of style became visible. He launched several campaigns in foreign policy, such as a failed humanitarian mission to [[Darfur]] and a proposal for the solution of the political crisis in [[Kosovo]]. On January 30, 2006, he left the [[Liberal Democracy of Slovenia]]. Shortly afterwards, he founded the [[Movement for Justice and Development (Slovenia)|Movement for Justice and Development]] and became its first president. He claimed this was not meant to be a political movement, but rather a wide initiative, aiming to "raise human consciousness and make the world a better place". On June 26, 2006, he announced that he would not be running for a second term in an interview on [[RTV Slovenia|TV Slovenia]]. === Conflict with the Government === [[File:Jacques Delors i Janez Drnovsek.jpg|thumb|Drnovšek with [[Jacques Delors]] in 1989]] The [[Slovenian parliamentary election, 2004|2004 legislative election]] brought further changes and a political swing to the right. [[Janez Janša]], the leader of a right-wing coalition, formed the new government. In Slovenia, this was the first time after 1992 that the President and the Prime Minister had represented opposing political factions for more than a few months. Between 2002-04, the relationship between President Drnovšek and Janez Janša, then leader of the opposition, were considered more than good{{cite web|url=http://www.mladina.si/tednik/200328/clanek/konvencija/index.print.html-l2|title=Tednik, številka 28, Iskalci vizije|publisher=Mladina.Si|date=14 July 2003|accessdate=23 October 2011}} and in the first year of cohabitation, no major problems arose. In the beginning of his term, Drnovšek, who was ill with [[kidney cancer]], stayed out of public view. When he reemerged in late 2005 he had already changed his lifestyle: he had become a [[vegan]] (though one of his colleagues in a televised interview mentioned their regular sunday visits to a pizzeria in Maxi market, Ljubljana), moved out of the capital into the countryside, and withdrew from party politics completely, ending his already frozen membership in the Liberal Democracy. Drnovšek's new approach to politics prompted one political commentator to nickname him "Slovenia's [[Gandhi]]".{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/09/world/europe/09drnovsek.html|title=Slovenian President Finds Peace and Wants to Share It|accessdate=5 September 2008|work=The New York Times|first=Nicholas|last=Wood}}{{cite news|url=http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/the_way_we_live/article2870371.ece|title=All hail the mystic President|accessdate=5 September 2008|publisher=Times Online|date=15 November 2007|location=London, UK|first=Martin|last=Fletcher}} The relationship between Drnovšek and the government quickly became tense. Disagreements began with Drnovšek's initiatives in foreign politics, aimed at solving major foreign conflicts, including those in [[Darfur conflict|Darfur]] and [[Kosovo]]. Initially, these initiatives were initially not openly opposed by the Prime Minister, but were criticized by the foreign minister [[Dimitrij Rupel]],{{cite web|url=http://www.mladina.si/tednik/200544/clanek/slo--zunanja_politika-ali_h_zerdin|title=Tednik, številka 44, Kosovska bitka: Drnovšek proti Ruplu|publisher=Mladina.Si|accessdate=23 October 2011}} Drnovšek's former collaborator and close political ally until 2004.{{cite web|url=http://24ur.com/novice/slovenija/rop-rupel-se-je-odlocil-po-svoje.html?ar=|title=Rop: Rupel se je odločil po svoje|publisher=24ur.com|date=26 June 2004|accessdate=23 October 2011}} A major clash between the two happened in Summer 2006, when disagreement arose over Drnovšek's attempt to intervene in the Darfur conflict.{{cite web|url=http://www.delo.si/clanek/o154553|title=Rupel kritičen do Drnovškovega urada|publisher=Delo.si|date=18 August 2006|accessdate=23 October 2011}} The disagreements moved from issues of domestic politics in October 2006, when Drnovšek publicly criticised the treatment of the Strojans, a [[Romani people|Romani]] family whose neighborhood had forced them to relocate, which in turn had subjected them to police supervision and limitation of movement. The disagreements however escalated when the parliamentary majority repeatedly rejected President's candidates for the Governor of the [[Bank of Slovenia]], beginning with the rejection of incumbent [[Mitja Gaspari]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ukom.gov.si/eng/slovenia/publications/slovenia-news/4274/4288|title=Gaspari Three Votes Short of Winning Second Term|accessdate=5 September 2008|publisher=Government communication office|date=6 February 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080305035710/http://www.ukom.gov.si/eng/slovenia/publications/slovenia-news/4274/4288|archivedate=5 March 2008}} The friction continued over the appointment of other state official nominees, including [[Constitutional Court of Slovenia|Constitutional Court]] judges. Although the President's political support suffered after his personal transformation, the polls nevertheless showed public backing of the President against an increasingly unpopular Government.{{cite web|url=http://www.mladina.si/tednik/200722/clanek/slo-tema--jure_trampus|title=Lepotica in zver|accessdate=5 September 2008|publisher=Mladina|language=Slovenian}} The tension reached its apex in May 2007, when the newly appointed director of the [[Slovenian Intelligence and Security Agency]] [[Matjaž Šinkovec]] unclassified several documents from the period before 2004, revealing, among other, that Drnovšek had used secret service funds for personal purposes between 2002-04. The President reacted with a harsh criticism of the government's policies, accusing the ruling coalition of abusing its power for personal delegitimations{{cite web|url=http://24ur.com/novice/slovenija/vlada-me-skusa-zlomiti.html|title='Vlada me skuša zlomiti'|publisher=24ur.com|accessdate=23 October 2011}} and labeled the Prime Minister as "the leader of the negative guys"{{cite web|author=Tekst: Rok Praprotnik|url=http://www.dnevnik.si/novice/slovenija/306840|title=Obletnica Dnevnikovega razkritja: Po letu dni afera Sova še vedno brez epiloga|publisher=Dnevnik.si|date=21 March 2008|accessdate=23 October 2011}} In the last months in office, Drnovšek continued his attacks on Prime Minister Janez Janša, who mostly remained silent on the issue. Drnovšek accused Janša of "fostering proto-totalitarian tendencies". He became a [[blog]]ger ([https://web.archive.org/web/20120502013837/http://janezd.blog.siol.net/ Janez D]), signing his posts as "Janez D" and expressing opinions on various issues from foreign policy, environmentalism, human relationships, religion, animal rights and personal growth. In his last months in office, he withdrew to a reclusive life again, devoting his time to the [[Movement for Justice and Development (Slovenia)|Movement for Justice and Development]] and the popularization of his lifestyle and views. ===Lifestyle changes=== During his time in office as the President of Slovenia, he wrote and published several books in [[spiritual philosophy]], including ''Misli o življenju in zavedanju'' ("Thoughts on Life and Consciousness"), ''Zlate misli o življenju in zavedanju'' ("Golden Thoughts on Life and Consciousness"), ''Bistvo sveta'' ("The Essence of the World"), and his last one called ''Pogovori'' or Dialogues. According to his own accounts, it took him only two or three weeks to write each of his books, due to – in his words – "the higher consciousness" he was able to access. His lifestyle was a mixture of elements from various traditions, including [[Hindu]] religious thought and the non-attachment of [[Buddhist]] philosophy. He also valued the indigenous traditions of the world. For example, he was present at the inauguration of [[Evo Morales]], the first native American president of [[Bolivia]], and later hosted Bolivian ethnic musicians in the [[Presidential Palace, Ljubljana|Presidential Palace]] in Ljubljana. After his diagnosis, Drnovšek became a [[veganism|vegan]], and claims that this greatly improved his health.[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/janez-drnovsek-slovenian-president-who-achieved-membership-of-the-eu-and-nato-for-the-former-yugoslav-republic-786789.html Janez Drnovsek: Slovenian president who achieved membership of the EU and Nato for the former Yugoslav republic] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705211518/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/janez-drnovsek-slovenian-president-who-achieved-membership-of-the-eu-and-nato-for-the-former-yugoslav-republic-786789.html|date=5 July 2015}} Because of his new lifestyle and the content of his books and blogs, he was often regarded as an adherent of the [[New Age]] movement, although he rejected such a qualification as being too narrow. ==Personal life== Drnovšek was fluent in six languages, [[Slovene language|Slovene]], [[Serbo-Croatian]], [[English language|English]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[French language|French]] and [[German language|German]].[http://www2.gov.si/up-rs/2002-2007/jd-ang.nsf/dokumentiweb/Zivljenjepis?OpenDocument Biography of Janez Drnovšek] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303172933/http://www2.gov.si/up-rs/2002-2007/jd-ang.nsf/dokumentiweb/Zivljenjepis?OpenDocument|date=3 March 2016}} He was divorced with one son, [[Jaša Drnovšek|Jaša]], who is a translator and journalist. In 2005, he found out about the existence of a daughter, [[Nana Forte]], otherwise a renowned composer.{{cite news|url=http://www.rtvslo.si/slovenija/drnovsek-o-nacrtih-in-svoji-hcerki/48268|title=Drnovšek o načrtih in svoji hčerki|language=Slovenian|trans-title=Drnovšek about his Plans and his Daughter|newspaper=MMC RTV Slovenia|date=1 January 2006}} His sister is [[Helena Drnovšek Zorko]],{{cite news|url=http://www.slovenskenovice.si/novice/slovenija/vlada-na-groznje-o-napadu-se-ne-odgovarja|title=Vlada na grožnje o napadu (še) ne odgovarja|language=Slovenian|trans-title=The Government Does not (yet) Respond to the Attack Threats|newspaper=Slovenske novice|date=31 January 2012}} who has been the Slovenian ambassador in Japan since September 2010.{{cite web|url=http://tokio.veleposlanistvo.si/index.php?id=3295&L=1|title=Ambassador|publisher=Embassy of the Republic of Slovenia Tokyo|accessdate=31 January 2012}} ===Death=== In 1999, Drnovšek had [[kidney cancer]] resulting in the removal of a kidney. In 2001, he had cancerous formations on his lungs and liver. He repeatedly claimed [[nature]] was the best cure, and spent most of his days at his home in Zaplana. He died there on February 23, 2008, aged 57. His body was cremated shortly afterwards. He was buried with honors in a private memorial service in his native Zagorje ob Savi, alongside his parents.{{Cite web|title=Janez Drnovsek, Slovenian Leader, Is Dead at 57|last=Press|first=The Associated|work=The New York Times|date=26 February 2008|accessdate=5 September 2016|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/02/26/world/europe/26drnovsek.html}} ==Books by Drnovšek== * ''Pogovori'' (''Conversations''). {{Infobox person | name = Jeje Odongo | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1951|7|9|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Uganda Protectorate]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = [[Nkumba University]]
{{small|([[Master of Arts|MA in International Relations & Diplomacy]])}} | occupation = Politician, military officer | years_active = 1979 — present | nationality = [[Uganda]]n | citizenship = [[Uganda]] | residence = [[Kampala]], [[Uganda]] | known_for = [[Politics]] | networth = | home_town = [[Amuria]] | title = | spouse = }} [[General]] '''Haji Abubaker Jeje Odongo''' is a [[Uganda]]n senior [[military officer]] and [[politician]] who has served as [[Ministry of Internal Affairs|Minister of Internal Affairs]] in the [[Cabinet of Uganda]] since 2016. Previously he served as [[Minister of Defence|Minister of State for Defence]] from February 2009 to June 2016.{{cite web |url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/12/671730 |title=Full Cabinet List |publisher=[[New Vision]] |date=18 February 2009 |author=Newvision Archive |accessdate=29 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150213214754/http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/12/671730 |archivedate=13 February 2015 |df= }} He was appointed as Minister of Internal Affairs on 6 June 2016.{{cite web|date=6 June 2016|author=Uganda State House | newspaper=[[Daily Monitor]] |format=PDF |accessdate=13 June 2016|location=Kampala| url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/blob/view/-/3235304/data/1345443/-/3o16hn/-/Museveni%2527s+cabinet.pdf| title=Museveni’s new cabinet list At 6 June 2016}} ==History== Jeje Odongo was born in [[Amuria District]], in the [[Teso sub-region]], in [[Eastern Region, Uganda|Eastern Uganda]]. He attended secondary school at [[Ngora High School]].{{cite web|url=http://www.monitor.co.ug/SpecialReports/Ngora-High-marks-100-years-as-Teso-education-anchor/688342-2349696-4wa59fz/index.html|title=Ngora High marks 100 years as Teso education anchor| publisher=Daily Monitor|date=16 June 2014|first=.|last=Richard Otim|accessdate=23 September 2016}} He entered the Ugandan army in 1979. He is one of the original twenty seven combatants who, together with [[Yoweri Museveni]], attacked Kabamba Military Barracks in February 1981 to start the [[Ugandan Bush War]], a guerrilla war that lasted from February 1981 until April 1986. Jeje Odongo was captured soon after the first NRA operation and was imprisoned in Luzira Maximum Security Prison.{{cite web|url=http://www.business.highbeam.com/3548/article-1G1-87056546/jeje-odongo-reveals-nra-roots|title=Jeje Odongo Reveals NRA Roots| publisher=Highbeam Business|date=10 June 2002|first=.|last=Africa News Service|accessdate=29 May 2014}} In 1994, Jeje Odongo was one of the ten army officers who represented the Ugandan military in the [[Constituent Assembly]] that drafted the 1995 Ugandan [[Constitution]]. In 1996, he was selected to replace Colonel Sserwanga Lwanga as the Political Commissar in the [[Uganda People's Defense Force]] (UPDF). Also in 1996, he contested the parliamentary seat for Amuria District in the [[Parliament of Uganda|Ugandan Parliament]]. He won and was appointed as Minister of Defence soon after he entered parliament. In 1998, he resigned his parliamentary seat and his cabinet position and was appointed Commander of the Army, taking over from Major General [[Mugisha Muntu]]. He served as army commander until 2001, when he was replaced by Major General [[James Kazini]]. In 2001, he was appointed as Minister without Portfolio, a position he occupied until 2004. In 2004, now at the rank of [[Lieutenant General]], Jeje Odongo was appointed as Minister of State for the Environment.{{cite web |url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/12/339500 |title=Museveni Raised to A Full General |publisher=[[New Vision]] |date=11 February 2004 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |first=and Geoffrey Kamali |last=Grace Matsiko |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140530024818/http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/12/339500 |archivedate=30 May 2014 |df= }} Between 2001 and 2006, he was one of 10 senior UPDF officers who represented the Ugandan military in the 8th Ugandan Parliament.{{cite web|title=UPDF Elects Its MPs |publisher=[[New Vision]] |date=17 February 2006 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |author=Newvision Archive |url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/482737 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140530023707/http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/482737 |archivedate=30 May 2014 |df= }} In May 2008, Jeje Odongo graduated with the degree of [[Master of Arts]] in International Relations and Diplomacy from [[Nkumba University]].{{cite web |url=http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/9/40/625763 |title=Is Jeje Odongo Warming Up for Diplomacy? |publisher=[[New Vision]] |date=2 May 2008 |accessdate=29 May 2014 |last=Newvision |first=Archive |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140530035824/http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/9/40/625763 |archivedate=30 May 2014 |df= }} On 16 February 2009, he was promoted to [[General]] and appointed [[Minister for Defence|Minister of State for Defence]].{{cite web|accessdate=29 May 2014|date=27 May 2011| url=https://www.facebook.com/note.php?note_id=10150208384704078&comments| title=Comprehensive List of New Cabinet Appointments & Dropped Ministers| publisher=[[Facebook|Facebook.com]]|author=State House Uganda}} After seven years in that post, he was instead appointed as Minister of Internal Affairs in the cabinet list announced on 6 June 2016.{{cite web|author=Uganda State House| url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/314964607/New-Cabinet |title=Uganda's New Cabinet As At 6 June 2016 |accessdate=13 June 2016 |date=6 June 2016 | publisher=Scribd.com }} ==See also== {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Salim Saleh]] * [[Elly Tumwine]] * [[Mugisha Muntu]] * [[James Kazini]] * [[Aronda Nyakairima]] * [[Cabinet of Uganda|Uganda Cabinet]] * [[Parliament of Uganda|Uganda Parliament]] * [[Amuria District]] }} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * '''Jofroi of Waterford''' ([[fl.]] 1300) was a French translator.
Probably a native of [[Waterford]] in Ireland, Jofroi was a [[Dominican Order|Dominican]], apparently based in [[Paris]], where he produced translations of Latin works into the French language. "He has no surviving connection with Ireland other than his name. It appears from an allusion in his work that he was based in Paris."<ref>Quote from Evelyn Mullally at [https://books.google.com/books?id=kVslRbrSH7QC&pg=PA186].</ref>
Jofroi's known translations are:
* translation of the ''[[Secretum Secretorum]]'', one of the most widely read books in Western Europe in the Late Middle Ages. Jofroi's French was later translated into English. * translation of a history of the Trojan War, authorship attributed to [[Dares Phrygius]] ([[pseudepigraphical]]). (Another book widely circulated in Latin in the Late Middle Ages.) * translation of a history of Rome by [[Eutropius (historian)]]. (Once again, a popular book in Latin). * a co-translation, with Servais Copale, of three prose poems
His original work is a catalogue of all the known [[History of wine|wines]] and [[History of beer|ales]] of [[Europe]].<ref>Henry 1986.</ref>
==References== <references /> * ''Hiberno-Norman literature'', Evelyn Mullally, in ''Settlement and Society in Medieval Ireland: Studies presented to F.X. Martin'', Dublin, 1988. * ''Un Texte œnologique de Jofroi de Waterford et Servais Copale'', Albert Henry, Romania 107 (1): 1-37, 1986.
{{authority control}}

{{Infobox person | name = Joseph Kibwetere | image = | image_size = 200px | caption = | birth_date = 1932 | birth_place = | disappeared_date = 17 March 2000<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=112232513|title=Joseph Kibweteere (1932 - 2000) - Find A Grave Memorial|website=www.findagrave.com|access-date=2017-07-09}}</ref> | | death_place = | occupation = Former Leader, [[Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God]] | salary = | networth = | spouse = | children = | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Joseph Kibwetere''' was one of the leaders of the [[Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dialogueireland.wordpress.com/2012/03/20/the-movement-for-the-restoration-of-the-ten-commandments-of-god/|title=The Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God|date=2012-03-20|website=Dialogue Ireland|access-date=2017-07-09}}</ref> a group that splintered from the [[Roman Catholic Church]] in [[Uganda]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cesnur.org/testi/uganda_002.htm|title=Tragedy in Uganda: the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God, a Post-Catholic Movement|last=MoreOrLess|website=www.cesnur.org|access-date=2017-07-09}}</ref> and became infamous after [[Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God#Apocalypse|778 of its members were found dead]]. Although it was initially assumed that Joseph died in the incident the Ugandan police shortly afterwards issued a warrant for arrest against Joseph Kibweteere and the other leaders of the group.<ref name="POISON">Cult in Uganda Poisoned Many, Police Say ''New York Times'' July 28, 2000</ref> In 2014 it was announced by the [[Uganda National Police]] that there were reports that Kibweteere was hiding in [[Malawi]].<ref name="MALAWAI">[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jOgZAcFRuyE NTVUganda; "Kanungu Massacre: Report claims Kibwetere is hiding in Malawi"]</ref>
==Biography== Many details of Kibweteere's life, and especially death, remain unclear. What is known is that he came from a strongly pious Catholic background and was likely wealthy by Ugandan standards. The second idea comes from the fact he ran for political office in 1980 and had enough land to donate for a school of his own design. The Catholic school he founded and led was apparently orthodox and at that point he had a positive image in the community. In 1960 he married a woman who would prove to outlive him.
The Uganda he lived in suffered from both religious and political upheaval which likely influenced him. The strongest of which may have been religious movements that emphasized miracles and [[Marian apparitions]]. In 1984 he claimed to be experiencing sightings of the Virgin Mary. This vision had been brought to him by [[Credonia Mwerinde]]. Mt Randz
==Religious acts== Around 1989 he came into contact with a woman named [[Credonia Mwerinde]], a prostitute who claimed she was looking to repent for her sins. She had a background of claimed experiences dating back further than Kibweteere. Credonia claimed that she could see the virgin Mary when looking at a stone on the mountains. The stone looked the spitting image of the Virgin Mary. Her father claimed to have had a vision of his dead daughter Evangelista as early as 1960. His children and grandchildren would be affected by this. By 1989, Credonia and her Ursula were travelling through Uganda spreading the family's message. When Credonia met Joseph he welcomed her with open arms and shared his own experiences. This would lead to their forming the [[Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God]].
After the death of Credonia's father, he became leader of the group. In the 1990s they strongly emphasized [[apocalypticism]] in their booklet ''A Timely Message from Heaven: The End of the Present Time''. Hence he led an elite group of six men and six women deemed to be the "new apostles." These apostles had an equal number of women because of the emphasis they placed on [[Mother Mary]] as instrumental in sweeping them toward heaven. The group stated several dates where it would be the end of the world, however, several of these dates passed by with no sign of an apocalypse. Reportedly he stated that the year 2000 would be followed by "year 1 of the new world." These and other claims had little effect on the wider world. For the most part he remained an obscure figure in Uganda and never formally split with the Catholic Church.
==Time of disappearance== In March 2000 the group began slaughtering cattle and buying massive amounts of [[Coca-Cola]]. These events did not initially raise alarm, but they were preparation for a feast before death. On March 17, Kibweteere apparently died in the group's [[mass suicide]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dialogueireland.wordpress.com/2012/03/20/the-movement-for-the-restoration-of-the-ten-commandments-of-god/|title=The Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God|date=2012-03-20|website=Dialogue Ireland|access-date=2017-07-09}}</ref> A member of Kibweteere's family stated that Joseph's actions were completely influenced by Credonia Mwerinde.
A great deal remains unclear about his story and the movement. The BBC reported that Kibweteere had been treated for [[bipolar disorder]] a year or so before the group suicide. At the time the Ugandan authorities considered him a fugitive and mass-murderer because they believed him to have escaped. The date and nature of the apocalypse they expected is debated. There is one camp that indicates they believed it would come in 1999 and that the 2000 suicide was caused by the failure of that prophecy. This would seem confirmed by some of their activities of 1999, but in their literature 2000 is often seen as the end year. The nature of his role and significance to the events is also disputed. Due to the circumstances of events, satisfactory answers to these and other questions may never be forthcoming. Kibwetere did all this in the Kanungu district in western Uganda.
==See also== * [[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]]

[[File:Lean Bear .jpg|thumb|Cheyenne Peace Chief believed to be Lean Bear. Taken 1863, in Washington D.C.]] '''Lean Bear''' ([[Cheyenne language|Cheyenne]] name '''Awoninahku''', 1813–1864), alternatively translated as '''Starving Bear''',<ref name=WestE>{{cite book|title=The Contested Plains: Indians, Goldseekers, and the Rush to Colorado|first=Elliott|last=West|year=1998|publisher=University Press of Kansas|location=Lawrence, KN|page=284}}</ref> was a [[Cheyenne]] peace chief.<ref name=r182>Ricky 182</ref> He was a member of the [[Council of Forty-four]],<ref name="The Earth is Weeping">{{cite book|last1=Cozzens|first1=Peter|title=The Earth is Weeping|publisher=Knopf}}</ref> a tribal governance devoted to maintaining peace with encroaching [[United States]] settlers. Lean Bear's most notable peace deals include the [[Treaty of Fort Wise]] <ref name="weeks"/> and a meeting with US President [[Abraham Lincoln]].<ref name="Harjo 145"/> His work towards peace between his people and the American settlers in the Southern Plains was cut short when he was killed by the [[1st Colorado Cavalry Regiment]] and violent retaliations ensued.<ref name="weeks"/>
== Personal life == Lean Bear suffered from vertigo, which commonly ran in the family. During a meeting with President [[Abraham Lincoln]] in 1863, he suffered an attack and spoke while seated in a chair.<ref name="Harjo 145">{{cite book|last1=Harjo|first1=Suzan|title=Nation to Nation|date=2014|publisher=Smithsonian Books|page=145}}</ref> Lean Bear brushed it off as a result of him simply being too nervous to stand.<ref name="Hoig145">{{cite book|last1=Hoig|first1=Stan|title=Peace Chiefs of the Cheyennes|date=1980|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|pages=145–146}}</ref>
===Relations=== Lean Bear had a brother called Bull Bear. In 1864, Bull Bear was the leader of the [[Dog Soldiers]], a position he would hold for many years.<ref name="Hoig84">{{cite book|last1=Hoig|first1=Stan|title=Peace Chiefs of the Cheyennes|date=1980|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|pages=84–86}}</ref>
Lean Bear also worked closely and served on the [[Council of Forty-four]] with fellow peace chief [[Black Kettle]], especially in the last decade of his life.<ref name="Hoig68"/>
== Political life == The first known account in history of Lean Bear is in 1851. He was roughly 35 at this time.<ref name="miller part 1">{{citation|title=Killing Lean Bear, Part 1|last1=Miller|first1=Courtney}}</ref> Agent [[Thomas Fitzpatrick (trapper)|Thomas Fitzpatrick]] was hosting a council in [[Fort Atkinson (Nebraska)|Fort Atkinson]] to convince plains tribes to attend a larger peace council at Fort Laramie later on.<ref name="Hoig68"/> The Comanche, Kiowa, Apache, Arapaho, and Cheyenne people went out to meet the soldiers and each other. They feasted and traded goods.<ref name="Hoig68"/> Fitzpatrick spoke with each group, and eventually convinced the Arapaho and Cheyenne tribes to attend the next peace council. The other tribes refused, wary about bringing their horses up north near tribes that were notorious for stealing horses.<ref name="Hoig68"/>
The troops were beginning to leave as the council ended when [[Edwin Vose Sumner|Colonel Sumner]] arrived at Fort Atkinson on his way to [[New Mexico]]. He stayed for a few days to trade and obtain some horses from the tribes in attendance.<ref name="Hoig68"/> After some time, the tribes began to freely explore both the fort and his camp, and Fitzpatrick grew nervous at the opportunities for conflict.<ref name="Hoig68"/> Lean Bear, who was in attendance at the peace council, was fascinated by the rings and bracelets on the hand of Sumner's wife and grabbed to get a better look. She reacted by pulling her hand back and screaming, provoking Sumner to rush forward to beat Lean Bear.<ref name="miller part 1" /><ref name="Hoig68">{{cite book|title=Peace Chiefs of the Cheyennes|date=July 31, 1990|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|pages=68–69|last1=Hoig|first1=Stan}}</ref> Because Cheyenne culture considers striking even a male child to be an insult, Lean Bear was incredibly indignant about the assault.<ref name="Hoig68"/> He painted his face and rode around his camp announcing his plans to attack the whites, inviting his brothers to join him.<ref name="Hoig68" /> Fitzpatrick initially refused to make reparations until some Kiowas and Comanches told him that the Cheyennes were getting ready to attack. A meeting was later arranged for Colonel Sumner to present Lean Bear with a blanket in apology, which he accepted.<ref name="miller part 1" />
===Council of Forty-Four=== Lean Bear was chosen to join the Council of Forty-four{{When|date=April 2017}} by past chiefs, as the council chose its own successors.<ref name="Hoig11">{{cite book|title=Peace Chiefs of the Cheyennes|date=July 31, 1990|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|pages=11–13|last1=Hoig|first1=Stan}}</ref> The council worked to sway their people towards a preference for peace with the Americans. Once named a chief of the council, one would have to give up membership in the war societies that new chiefs often came from.<ref name="Hoig11"/> These efforts contrasted with the increasingly vocal [[Dog Soldiers]], bands of Cheyennes who held a longstanding opposition to white settlement and did not wait to cooperate and make peace.<ref name="half breed 161">{{cite book|last1=Halaas|first1=David|last2=Masich|first2=Andrew|title=Halfbreed|date=March 16, 2005|publisher=Da Capo Press|page=161}}</ref> They stole livestock and fought with troops and settlers.<ref name="campbell">{{cite book|last1=Campbell|first1=Ballard|title=Disasters, Accidents, and Crises in American History:|date=2008|publisher=InfoBase Publishing|page=114}}</ref> The Dog Soldiers were exiled for their behavior and deemed renegades, operating independently of the tribe. Nonetheless, their provocative nature caused a lot of trouble for the peace-seeking Cheyennes.<ref name="half breed 117">{{cite book|last1=Halaas|first1=David|last2=Masich|first2=Andrew|title=Halfbreed|date=March 16, 2005|publisher=Da Capo Press|pages=117–118}}</ref>
===Treaty of Fort Wise=== On October 1857, Chief Lean Bear and three other Cheyenne chiefs approached [[William Bent]] with concern about attacks on his people by Sumner's troops along the [[Republican River]].<ref name="miller part 1"/> Bent then sent a letter to Washington D.C. on their behalf, stating that the Cheyenne chiefs would like to speak with someone from the government. The response came in 1860, when Commissioner A.B. Greenwood met the chiefs at Fort Wise.<ref name="Hoig68"/><ref name="Hoig62"/> Chief Lean Bear was one of the principal signers in the [[Treaty of Fort Wise]] in 1861.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Fixico|first1=Donald|title=Treaties with American Indians|date=December 12, 2007|publisher=ABC-CLIO|pages=351–352}}</ref> This treaty was made with Cheyenne and [[Arapaho]] chiefs, cutting roughly 40 million acres of land from their territory.<ref name="NPS 2"/>
There were mixed responses to the deal, including scorn from the Dog Soldiers, because only six Cheyenne chiefs were present to sign the treaty, when all forty-four are typically needed when treaties and alliances are being made.<ref name="Hoig145"/> The deal was made in an attempt to keep peace as pioneers spread near Indian territory, but the land reduction and the continued encroachment by white settlers only heightened tensions.<ref name="NPS 2">{{cite web|last1=Sainio|first1=Eric|title=A Tale of Two Treaties|url=https://www.nps.gov/sand/learn/news/a-tale-of-two-treaties.htm|website=National Park Service|accessdate=23 April 2017}}</ref> The Cheyennes were not ready to forced into the confines of the small reserve, where there were not many buffalo, allocated for them in the treaty.<ref name="Hoig62">{{cite book|title=Peace Chiefs of the Cheyennes|date=July 31, 1990|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|page=62|last1=Hoig|first1=Stan}}</ref>
=== Meeting in Washington D.C. === [[File:Lincoln and Peace Chiefs 1863.jpg|thumb|The delegation of chiefs meeting with Lincoln on March 27, 1863. Lean Bear is believed to be one of the people in the lower left of the image.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Peace Chiefs of the Cheyennes|last=Hoig|first=Stan|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|year=1990|isbn=|location=|pages=71}}</ref>]] On March 27, 1863, a delegation of chiefs and two women met with President [[Abraham Lincoln]] in the East room of the White House.<ref name="Hoig70">{{cite book|title=Peace Chiefs of the Cheyennes|date=July 31, 1990|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|pages=70–73|last1=Hoig|first1=Stan}}</ref> The meeting was called after skirmishes with Native tribes and white settlers created fear that southern plains tribes would side with the confederacy.<ref name="Hoig68"/> Lincoln was hoping to persuade Native Nations to either ally with the Union, or pledge neutrality.<ref name="Harjo 145" />
Lincoln welcomed the chiefs, explaining that white Americans had conquered an expansive population, territory, and wealth that white Americans had gained.<ref name="Malcolmson">{{cite book|last1=Malcolmson|first1=Scott|title=One Drop of Blood: The American Misadventure of Race|pages=94–95}}</ref> Lean Bear implored the president to stop his white Americans from being violent so that Indians and whites alike could travel across the plains without risk. Lincoln told the chiefs that their Native people were naturally more tempted to violence.<ref name="Malcolmson" /> He further explained that in order to survive and be prosperous, the Native Americans would have to adopt methods of cultivating the land that were more similar to the way of the whites.<ref name="NPS" /><ref name="Harjo 146">{{cite book|last1=Harjo|first1=Suzan|title=Nation to Nation|date=2014|publisher=Smithsonian Books|page=146}}</ref> Lincoln also requested that the southern Plains Indians remain neutral in the [[American Civil War]], ready to provide peace medals to those that he could reach an agreement with.<ref name="Harjo 145" /> The chiefs complied, promising to uphold peace treaties and not align with the confederacy.<ref name="Harjo 147">{{cite book|last1=Harjo|first1=Suzan|title=Nation to Nation|date=2014|publisher=Smithsonian Books|page=147}}</ref> Lean Bear then made a request to the president to expedite his and the other chiefs' journey home.<ref name="The Earth is Weeping" />
==Killing of Lean Bear== On May 16, 1864, less than 15 months after meeting Lincoln in Washington,<ref name = "NPS" /> Lean Bear, Black Kettle, and others in the tribe were camping on their buffalo hunting grounds near [[Ash Creek Township, Ellsworth County, Kansas|Ash Creek]]. The [[1st Colorado Cavalry Regiment|1st Colorado Regiment]], under the command of Lieutenant [[George Eayre]], approached the group. Although there had been a fight around a month previous involving Cheyenne Dog Soldiers at Fremont's Orchard, Lean Bear was confident that the violence wouldn't be associated with his peaceful tribe and was not concerned as the soldiers got closer.<ref name="half breed 127">{{cite book|last1=Halaas|first1=David|last2=Masich|first2=Andrew|title=Halfbreed|date=March 16, 2005|publisher=Da Capo Press|page=127}}</ref><ref name="NPS" /><ref name="weeks">{{cite book|last1=Weeks|first1=Philip|title=Farewell, My Nation: The American Indian and the United States in the Nineteenth Century|date=February 16, 2016|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|page=142}}</ref> Positive that this would be a peaceful encounter, Lean Bear went alone to meet the militia to show his peaceful intentions.<ref name="half breed 117"/> On his chest, Lean Bear proudly wore his peace medal that he had received on his trip to Washington D.C. in 1863. In his hand, he held an official document signed by President Lincoln stating that he was peaceful and friendly with whites.<ref name="half breed 117"/> What Lean Bear did not realize was that Eayre's troops were operating under orders from Colonel [[John M. Chivington]] to "kill Cheyennes whenever and wherever found."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Utley|first1=Robert|title=Indian Frontier of the American West 1846-1890|publisher=Albuquerque: University of New Mexico Press|page=89}}</ref> Eayre ordered his men to shoot Lean Bear, who was wounded and fell off his horse. He was then shot repeatedly by the soldiers as they rode past his body on the ground.<ref name="half breed 117"/>
The troops rode on to attack other Cheyennes at the camp, killing at least one more warrior and wounding many others at the camp.<ref name="half breed 117"/><ref name="Miller Part 2">{{Cite web|url=http://courtneymillerauthor.com/2014/05/killing-lean-bear-part-2/|title=Killing Lean Bear Part 2|last=Miller|first=Courtney|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name="weeks"/> Cheyenne warriors armed themselves and mounted their horses, ready to retaliate.<ref name = "weeks"/> Black Kettle rode out to de-escalate the situation, stopping any further violence, and the American troops retreated to [[Fort Larned]].
===Aftermath of the killing=== Rising tensions caused by the death of Lean Bear, along with Eayre's other Indian camp raids, is heavily attributed to the [[Sand Creek Massacre]] that occurred six months later.<ref name="NPS"/> Lean Bear's brother, Bull Bear, was livid after the killing and felt compelled to violence against the white men, a desire he had never felt before.<ref name="Bull Bear"/> Bull Bear remarked that his brother had died while trying to keep peace with the settlers, and he expected to die in the same way.<ref name="Hoig11"/> He called for war but was shot down at a meeting with Wynkoop, the Fort Lyon Commander, on September 10, 1864.<ref name ="Bull Bear">{{cite book|last1=Thrapp|first1=Dan|title=Encyclopedia of Frontier Biography: A-F|date=June 1, 1991|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|page=188}}</ref> Despite Black Kettle's best efforts to keep the peace, attacks by Native warriors in the Southern Plains skyrocketed as the vengeful tribes burned ranches and trails, kidnapping settlers and their livestock.<ref name="weeks"/> Over time, the Dog Soldiers' popularity rose, and they overrode Black Kettle's efforts to resist war.<ref name="Hoig11"/> The Governor of Colorado issued a proclamation giving each citizen permission and encouragement to retaliate by killing any Indians and seek compensation for stolen property.<ref name="weeks"/>
==Legacy== There are no confirmed images of Lean Bear. There are only images and paintings of the full room in 1863 when the delegation went to meet president Lincoln. There are many differing accounts on the identities of each chief in the image.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cheyenne Biography: Chief Lean Bear.|url=https://laef.newsvine.com/_news/2007/01/25/532762-cheyenne-biography-chief-lean-bear|website=Newsvine|accessdate=15 April 2017}}</ref> In common usage by sources about Lean Bear is an image of a Cheyenne peace chief who is typically believed to be Lean Bear.<ref name="NPS">{{cite web|last1=Moore|first1=Craig|title=Chief Lean Bear Murder|url=https://www.nps.gov/sand/learn/news/chief-lean-bear-murder.htm|website=National Park Service|accessdate=10 April 2017}}</ref>
Parts of Lean Bear's life are described in the book of folklore, ''By Cheyenne Campfires'', compiled by [[George Bird Grinnell]].

{{more footnotes|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox military person | native_name = Лев Николаевич Зиньковский | native_name_lang = rus | image = Lev-Zadov.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1893|4|11}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|1938|9|25|1893|4|11}} | birth_place = Veselaya Yevreyka, [[Yekaterinoslav Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]] | death_place = [[Kiev]], [[Ukrainian SSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | placeofburial = [[Darnytsia]], Kiev, [[Ukraine]] | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial_coordinates = | nickname = Leva, Levka the bandit | allegiance = {{flagicon image|Flag of Russian SFSR (1918-1937).svg}} [[Red Army]] (1918)
{{flagicon image|Black flag.svg}} [[Revolutionary Insurrectionary Army of Ukraine]] (1918-1921)
{{flagicon image|Flag of the Soviet Union.svg}} [[Soviet Union]] (1924-1938) | branch = Black Army military intelligence (1918-1921)
[[OGPU]] (1924-1934) | serviceyears = 1918-1938 | rank = | servicenumber = | unit = | commands = | battles = | battles_label = | awards = | relations = | laterwork = | signature = | website = }} '''Lev Nikolaevich Zadov (Zinkovsky)''' ({{lang-ru|Лев Николаевич ("Лёвка") Задов (Зиньковский)}}) April 11, 1893 - September 25, 1938, [[Kiev]] was chief of military intelligence of the [[Revolutionary Insurrectionary Army of Ukraine]], and later an [[OGPU]] operative. Born Lev Zadov, he changed his last name to Zinkovsky. ==Early years== Lev Zadov was born in the [[Jewish agricultural colonies in the Russian Empire|Russian Jewish agricultural colony]] [http://www.shtetlinks.jewishgen.org/Colonies_of_Ukraine/Veselaya.htm Veselaya]. About 1898-1900 his family fell on hard times and moved to [[Donetsk|Yuzovka]], where his father found work as a coachman. Zadov graduated at a Jewish [[heder|elementary school]] there and started to work as a manual laborer at a mill, later working at Yuzovka Metallurgical Works. ==Anarchist underground and penal labour== Lev Zadov joined the Yuzovka Metallurgical Works [[Anarchism|anarchist]] group before 1912. He participated in several armed robberies (the then-popular way for anarchist groups to finance their activities), as well as distributing propaganda pamphlets. He was arrested and convicted in 1913 for robbery of a [[post office]] and sentenced to 8 years of [[penal labour]]. ==From February Revolution to Makhno== Zadov was released after the [[February Revolution]] in February 1917 along with other revolutionary prisoners. He was elected a member of the city [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] in Yuzovka soon after that. Zadov had been instrumental in organizing the anarchist paramilitary force in Yuzovka and joined the [[Red Army]] in Spring 1918 with this group. His junior brother Daniel had been member of the force too. Zadov quickly rose through the ranks and became deputy regiment commander. Zadov's regiment fought advancing German Army and [[Tsentralna Rada]] troops, but was defeated and withdrew toward [[Volgograd|Tsaritsyn]]. The Zadov brothers defected from the Red Army there and returned to the Ukraine to join the anarchists. ==Makhnovist== Lev Zadov joined [[Nestor Makhno]]'s [[Guerrilla warfare|guerrillas]] in August 1918 and quickly became chief of military intelligence of [[the Revolutionary Insurrectionary Army of Ukraine]] (also known as the Black Army). According to numerous eyewitnesses, he was a member of Makhno's inner circle and friend of Makhno's wife. Zadov is credited with personally saving Makhno's life several times during skirmishes with Red Army forces. On August 28, 1921 Zadov organized the escape of remnants of Makhnovist guerrilla forces to [[Romania]]. Romanian security services recruited him and his brother in 1924 to join an anti-Soviet underground group to be sent to the [[Soviet Union]]. ==OGPU operative== After crossing the Soviet-Romanian border Zadov surrendered to Soviet authorities and joined the [[KGB|OGPU]], working in their office in [[Odessa]]. Daniel Zadov (Zotov) became an OGPU operative in [[Tiraspol]]. Zadov had been instrumental in the annihilation of several Anti-Soviet militant groups. He is credited with running one of the most successful Soviet intelligence operations against Romania, and had been awarded with a personal gilded weapon for the "successful fight against counter-revolution". The Zadov brothers were arrested during the [[Great Purge]] in September 1937 and accused of collaboration with Romanian security services. The Zadov brothers' trial took place on September 25, 1938 and lasted only 15 minutes. Both Lev and Daniel were convicted of "collaboration with foreign secret services" and executed by firing squad on September 25, 1938. ==Personal life== Lev Zadov married Vera Matvienko in 1925 and had a daughter, Alla Zinkovskaya (born 1925), and son, Vadim Zinkovsky (born 1926). Alla Zinkovskaya volunteered to join Red Army in the beginning of the [[Soviet-German War]]. She was killed on June 13, 1942http://obd-memorial.ru/html/info.htm?id=75799982 fighting in the [[Siege of Sevastopol (1941-1942)|Sevastopol]]. Vadim joined the Red Army in 1944 (age 18) and became a [[Officer (armed forces)|commissioned officer]]. Vadim Zinkovsky retired from the [[Soviet Army]] as a [[colonel]] in 1977. ==Cultural depiction== Lev Zadov is depicted in [[Aleksey Nikolayevich Tolstoy]]'s "The Road to Calvary" novels as a ruthless but cowardly killer, who participates in numerous atrocities against civilians but shies away from battle engagements. The phrases "Hide your teeth or I'll swing them out" and "I'm Leva Zadov, I'll speak and you'll fear" attributed to him by Tolstoy, became part of Russian [[slang]]. It is proven today that Tolstoy used a pamphlet published in 1924 in [[Kiev]] for his information on Zadov. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.hrono.info/biograf/bio_z/zadov.html Зиньковский-Задов Лев Николаевич] (Russian) * [http://www.makhno.ru/other/20.php Лев Яруцкий. Кто, он Лева Задов?] (Russian) * [http://www.makhno.ru/other/21.php Свинцовая примочка главному "скрипачу"] (Russian) {{Anarchism}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Zadov, Lev}} [[Category:1893 births]] [[Category:1938 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century executions for treason]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Ukraine]] [[Category:NKVD officers]] [[Category:Makhnovism]] [[Category:People of the Russian Civil War]] [[Category:People of the Russian Revolution]] [[Category:Anarchist partisans]] [[Category:Ukrainian Jews]] [[Category:Imperial Russian Jews]] [[Category:Soviet Jews]] [[Category:Ukrainian anarchists]] [[Category:People executed for treason against the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Great Purge victims from Ukraine]] [[Category:Jewish people executed by the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Soviet anarchists]]

page.title: List of new memorials to Robert Hooke 2005 – 2009

revision.text:
[[Robert Hooke]], a major figure of 17th century [[England]], died essentially unmemorialized. With no immediate family, and with personal disputes with many members of the [[Royal Society]], no memorials were erected in his honor on the occasion of his death. On the occasion of the [[tercentenary]] of his death in 2003, several efforts were made to address this situation.
== Carved Stone Memorials == === Westminster Abbey === [[Image:Inscription-to-Hooke-in-Westminster-Abbey.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Inscription to Hooke in Westminster Abbey.]]
Eddie Smith, former Undermaster and archivist at [[Westminster School]] of which Hooke was a member, worked tirelessly on Hooke's behalf to get him a small memorial in [[Westminster Abbey]]. The work took years but eventually in 2005 one was unveiled. The inscription reads "Robert Hooke 1703" and is carved from one of the black marble tiles in the floor beneath the Lantern, near the pulpit. This is appropriate as Hooke was responsible for the laying of this floor.
=== The Monument === [[Image:Carved-inscription-on-Monument.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Inscription to Hooke on The Monument, London.]] Hooke's name was omitted from the [[Monument to the Great Fire of London]] (known generally as just "The Monument"), erected to commemorate the [[Great Fire of London]] in 1666, as [[Sir Christopher Wren]] has generally been given credit for the design of this monument. The new inscription acknowledges Hooke’s role in the monument's development.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Hooke at last remembered | journal = Petersfield Post | date=7 February 2007| page = 13 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title = Monument | publisher = Dept of Planning and Transportation, City of London | year = 2008 | pages = 13–14 }}</ref>
As part of a project to improve the area around the pillar in 2007 it was possible to take a space in the paving for a large ({{convert|16|sqft|m2}}) carved stone. The stone was quarried at Caithness and made its long journey down to London to be carved at the workshop of Richard Kindersley. It can be seen from the entrance to the Monument Underground Station and is now included in sightseeing tours for tourists.
The wording on the memorial was written by [[Dr. Allan Chapman]].
=== St Paul's Cathedral === [[Image:Engraved-metal-bookworm.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Inscription to Hooke in St. Paul's Cathedral.]] Hooke's memorial at [[St. Paul's Cathedral]]<ref>{{cite journal | title = Photograph of the new memorial in St. Paul's Cathedral to Robert Hooke | journal = Dome, The magazine of the Friends of St. Paul's Cathedral | issue = 46 | pages = 16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | title = Robert Hooke - A memorial in St. Paul's | journal = Tablets | issue = 49 | page = 7 | year = Spring 2009 | publisher = Masons livery company }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | title = Memorial to Hooke is highlight of year| journal = Petersfield Post | date=17 December 2008| page = 13 }}</ref> is on the wall in the crypt of the cathedral, next to the tomb of Sir Christopher Wren. The quotation around the edge is from ''[[Micrographia]]'', Hooke's amazing book, published in 1665.
At the bottom of the memorial is an engraved metal bookworm in brass and chrome, recessed into the stone surface.
As the crypt is rather a dark place, a pale, ivory-coloured stone was chosen and the carved letters were painted with blue and brownish-red watercolour to make them more easily readable.
The memorial was dedicated by the Dean of St. Paul's after a special Evensong.
== Painted Memorials == Artist Rita Greer has created several new images of Hooke and donated them to various sites.
=== Gresham College, City of London === This portrait in oils is the first of a series of memorial portraits. It shows a list of Hooke's interests and skills. It now hangs in the hall at [[Gresham College]]<ref>{{cite journal | title = Rita’s portraits of Hooke sought after across UK | journal = Petersfield Post | issue = May 21 | year = 2008 | pages = 13 }}</ref> in the [[City of London]]. Hooke was Professor of Geometry for many years at the original Gresham College, at the site where the NatWest Tower now stands.
=== Isle of Wight === This painting shows Hooke as a child on the [[Isle of Wight]], holding the model boat he made, with the church of All Saints (where his father was curate) in the background and the [[river medina]].
=== The Open University, Milton Keynes === This memorial painting now hangs in the Seminar Room of the Robert Hooke Science Building at the [[Open University]]<ref>{{cite journal | title = Unveiling of memorial portrait of Robert Hooke as astronomer and inventor. | journal = Openhouse. Newspaper for the staff of The Open University | issue = 421 | year = 2009 }}</ref> in [[Milton Keynes]]. It shows Hooke concerned with minute objects and huge objects. The emphasis is on astronomy. It was unveiled in February 2009.
=== Willen Church near Milton Keynes === [[Church of St Mary Magdalene, Willen|Church of St Mary Magdalene]] is Hooke's only remaining church, not far from the Open University. He designed it for Dr. Richard Busby, the first headmaster of Westminster School. The memorial painting shows the church in the background.
=== University of Oxford === This memorial was commissioned for the Master's office at the Department of Engineering Science <ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.eng.ox.ac.uk/events/hooke-unveiling.html | title = New Portrait of Robert Hooke, FRS, unveiled | date = 11 June 2009 | publisher = Department of Engineering Science, [[Oxford University]]}}</ref> of [[Oxford University]] in 2009. It shows a portrait of Robert Hooke as an engineer with a few of his inventions – the [[universal joint]], [[wheel barometer]] and [[anchor escapement|pocket watch]]. Other features of his work are the spring, an optic and his microscope with open pages of his book ''Micrographia''. He holds a chain to make a [[catenary arch]]. Through the window can be seen the [[Bodleian Library]] and the [[Sheldonian Theatre]], linking him with Oxford where he was an undergraduate.
{{Gallery | title = Rita Greer memorial paintings of Robert Hooke | lines = 2 |File:18 Memorial at Gresham College.JPG|alt1=Hooke Memorial at Gresham College|Memorial at [[Gresham College]]. |File:2 Robert Hooke on the Isle of Wight.JPG|alt2=Hooke Memorial at Isle of Wight|Robert Hooke on the [[Isle of Wight]]. |File:15 Memorial Portrait at The Open University.JPG|alt3=Hooke at the Open University|Memorial Portrait at The [[Open University]]. |File:19 Willen Church.JPG|alt4=Hooke in front of Willen Church|Hooke in front of Willen Church. |File:17 Robert Hooke Engineer.JPG|alt5=Hooke with engineering paraphernalia|Robert Hooke Engineer }}

{{for|the American mathematician|Louise Hay (mathematician)}} {{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Louise L. Hay | image = LouiseHay.JPG | imagesize = 150px | caption = Louise L. Hay in 2008. | pseudonym = Lois Hayes Modesto Junior College 1942 | birth_name = Helen Vera Lunney | birth_date = {{Birth date|1926|10|08}} | birth_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|2017|08|30|1926|10|08}} | death_place = | occupation = Author, [[Motivational speaker|Professional speaker]], | nationality = American | period = | genre = [[Self-help]], [[Motivation]]al | subject = | movement = | notableworks =''[[You Can Heal Your Life]]'' (1984) | influences = | influenced = | signature = | website = [http://www.louisehay.com louisehay.com] | footnotes = }} {{New Thought}} '''Louise Lynn Hay''' (October 8, 1926 – August 30, 2017) was an American motivational author and the founder of [[Hay House]]. She authored several [[New Thought]] [[self-help]] books, including the 1984 book, ''[[You Can Heal Your Life]]''.
==Biography== Born Helen Vera Lunney in Los Angeles to parents Henry John Lunney (1901–1998) and Veronica Chwala (1894–1985), Hay recounted her life story in an interview with Mark Oppenheimer of ''[[The New York Times]]'' in May 2008.<ref name="Oppenheimer"/> In it, Hay stated that she was born in [[Los Angeles]] to a poor mother who remarried Louise's violent stepfather Ernest Carl Wanzenreid (1903-1992), who physically abused her and her mother. According to Hay, when she was about 5, she was raped by a neighbor. At 15, she dropped out of [[University High School (Los Angeles)|University High School]] in Los Angeles without a diploma, became pregnant and, on her 16th birthday, gave up her newborn baby girl for adoption. She then moved to Chicago, where she worked in low-paying jobs. In 1950, she moved on again, to New York. At this point she changed her first name, and began a career as a fashion model. She achieved success, working for [[Bill Blass]], [[Oleg Cassini]], and [[Pauline Trigère]]. In 1954, she married the English businessman Andrew Hay (1928-2001); after 14 years of marriage, she felt devastated when he left her for another woman, Sharman Douglas (1928-1996).<ref name="Oppenheimer"/>
Hay said that about this time she found the First Church of Religious Science on 48th Street, which taught her the transformative power of thought. Hay revealed that here she studied the [[New Thought]] works of authors like [[Florence Scovel Shinn]], who claimed that positive thinking could change people’s material circumstances, and the [[Religious Science]] founder [[Ernest Holmes]], who taught that [[Optimism|positive thinking]] could heal the body.<ref name=Holmes>{{cite book|last=Holmes|first=Ernest|title=The Science of Mind|year=1926|publisher=Robert M. McBride & Co.|location=New York|isbn=0-87477-865-4}}</ref>
By Hay's account, in the early 1970s she became a Religious Science practitioner. In this role she led people in spoken [[Affirmations (New Age)|affirmations]], which she believes would cure their illnesses, and became popular as a workshop leader. She also recalled how she had studied [[Transcendental Meditation]] with the [[Maharishi Mahesh Yogi]] at the [[Maharishi University of Management|Maharishi International University]] in [[Fairfield, Iowa]].<ref name="Oppenheimer"/>
Hay described how in 1977 or 1978 she was diagnosed with "incurable" [[cervical cancer]], and how she came to the conclusion that by holding on to her resentment for her childhood abuse and rape she had contributed to its onset. She reported how she had refused conventional medical treatment, and began a regime of forgiveness, coupled with therapy, nutrition, [[reflexology]], and occasional colonic [[enema]]s. She claimed in the interview that she rid herself of the cancer by this method, but, while swearing to its truth, admitted that she had outlived every doctor who could confirm this story.<ref name="Oppenheimer">Mark Oppenheimer (May 4, 2008), [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/04/magazine/04Hay-t.html "The Queen of the New Age"], ''[[The New York Times Magazine]]'', retrieved May 2008.</ref>
In 1976, Hay wrote her first book, ''Heal Your Body'', which began as a small pamphlet containing a list of different bodily ailments and their “probable” metaphysical causes.<ref name="Oppenheimer"/> This pamphlet was later enlarged and extended into her book ''You Can Heal Your Life'', published in 1984.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/You-Can-Heal-Your-Life/dp/0937611018|title=Amazon.com|last=|first=|date=|website=Amazon|publisher=|archiveurl=|archive-date=|deadurl=|access-date=|df=}}</ref> In February 2008, it was second on the New York Times miscellaneous paperback best-sellers list.<ref>[http://www.commercialappeal.com/news/2008/feb/24/new-york-times-best-sellers/ New York Times Best-Sellers] ''The New York Times'', February 23, 2008. </ref>
Around the same time she began leading support groups for people living with [[HIV/AIDS]], which she called ''"Hay Rides"''.<ref name="Oppenheimer"/> These grew from a few people in her living room to hundreds of men in a large hall in [[West Hollywood, California]]. Her work with AIDS patients drew fame and she was invited to appear on ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'' and ''[[The Phil Donahue Show]]'' in the same week, in March 1988. Following this, ''[[You Can Heal Your Life]]'' immediately landed on the New York Times best-seller list. More than 50 million copies sold around the world in over 30 languages<ref name="Oppenheimer"/><ref>[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/main.jhtml?xml=/health/2007/04/23/hlouise123.xml "Louise Hay Interview"] ''The Telegraph'', April 23, 2007. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070429000056/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/health/main.jhtml?xml=%2Fhealth%2F2007%2F04%2F23%2Fhlouise123.xml |date=April 29, 2007 }}</ref> and it also has been made into a movie.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youcanhealyourlifemovie.com/|title=You Can Heal Your Life: The Movie|publisher=|access-date=October 17, 2016}}</ref> ''You Can Heal Your Life'' is also included in the book ''50 Self-Help Classics''<ref>[http://www.butler-bowdon.com/youcanheal.html Review of ''You Can Heal Your Life''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081216083710/http://www.butler-bowdon.com/youcanheal.html |date=2008-12-16 }}, ''50 Self-Help Classics''</ref> for being significant in its field.
Hay wrote, on page 225 of her book, (December 2008 printing) that the book has "... sold more than thirty five million copies".<ref>[[List of best-selling books#Between 30 million and 50 million copies]]</ref> It was announced in 2011 that ''You Can Heal your Life'' had reached 40 million sales.<ref> [http://www.getbusythriving.com/self-empowerment-louise-hay.html Get Busy Thriving]</ref>
Louise Hay died in her sleep on the morning of August 30, 2017 at age 90.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theeventchronicle.com/metaphysics/spiritual/louise-hay-transitioned-morning-august-30-2017/#|title=Louise Hay transitioned the morning of August 30, 2017|date=2017-09-01|work=The Event Chronicle|access-date=2018-05-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Publishing== In 1984, Hay established the [[Hay House]] publishing firm. In 1988 [[Reid Tracy]] joined the company as an accountant and would eventually become its CEO. The business flourished and attracted various writers. {{As of|2015}} Hay House is the primary publisher of books and audio books by over 130 authors, including [[Deepak Chopra]] and [[Doreen Virtue]], as well as many books by [[Wayne Dyer]]. [[Hay House]] also publishes the teachings of "Abraham" as channeled through [[Esther Hicks]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hayhouse.co.uk/authors/5897/hay-house|title=Hay House - Author Biography|author=|date=|website=www.hayhouse.co.uk|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref>
In addition to running her publishing company, Hay ran a charitable organization called the Hay Foundation, which she founded in 1985.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hayfoundation.org/|title=The Hay Foundation - Founded In 1986 By Louise Hay|author=|date=|website=Hay Foundation|accessdate=17 April 2018}}</ref>
In 2008, a movie about Louise Hay's life was released, titled ''You Can Heal Your Life''. In Hay's own words on the film's official Web site: "This movie is the story of my life, my teachings, and how I've applied the principles of my teachings to my own life." The movie also features notable speakers and authors in the field of [[personal development]] including [[Gregg Braden]], [[Wayne Dyer]], [[Gay Hendricks]], [[Esther Hicks|Esther and Jerry Hicks]], and [[Doreen Virtue]]; it was directed by Emmy Award-winning director [[Michael A. Goorjian]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youcanhealyourlifemovie.com/|title=You Can Heal Your Life: The Movie|publisher=|access-date=17 October 2016}}</ref> In the same year Louise Hay won a Minerva Award at [[The Women's Conference]].<ref> [http://www.louisehay.com/about-louise/first-lady-maria-shriver-presents-2008-minerva-award-to-louise-hay.php Louise Hay- Official site] </ref>
In September 2011, Hay and Cheryl Richardson released their book ''You Can Create An Exceptional Life''.
