|caption= |location=Avraham Avinu neighborhood in [[Hebron]], [[West Bank]] |target= |date=26 March 2001
4:00 pm ([[Greenwich Mean Time|GMT]]+2) |time-begin= |time-end= |timezone= |type=Shooting attack |fatalities=a ten-month-old Israeli infant (Shalhevet Pass) |injuries= |perps = Lone Palestinian assailant (Mahmud Amru), member of the [[Tanzim]] militant group{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9M8vAQAAIAAJ&q=Shalhevet+Pass&dq=Shalhevet+Pass&hl=en&ei=i0OBTbTdApSksQO0ubD_AQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAzge |title=Palestinian secular terrorism: profiles of Fatah, Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command and the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine|author=Yonah Alexander|year=2003|accessdate=16 March 2011}} |weapons=[[Sniper rifle]] }} [[File:Shalhevet Pass.jpg|thumb|200px| Shalhevet Pass with her mother.]] The '''murder of Shalhevet Pass''' was a shooting attack which was carried out on March 26, 2001, in Hebron, [[West Bank]], in which a [[Palestinian Arabs|Palestinian]] [[sniper]] killed the ten-month-old [[Israel]]i [[infant]] Shalhevet Pass. The event shocked the Israeli public, partly because an investigation ruled that the sniper had deliberately aimed for the baby. According to Deborah Sontag of [[New York Times]], the murder became a "potent Israeli symbol as an innocent victim of the raging violence".Deborah Sontag, [https://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/02/world/israeli-baby-s-funeral-becomes-focus-of-settler-militancy.html Israeli Baby's Funeral Becomes Focus of Settler Militancy]. nytimes.com, 2 April 2001. ==The murder== On March 26, 2001, at 4:00 pm, Shalhevet was shot in her [[stroller]] while her parents were accompanying her from a parking lot by the Avraham Avinu neighborhood in [[Hebron]], where she and her family lived.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6aLsz14aKJsC&pg=PA64&dq=Shalhevet+Pass&hl=en&ei=szqBTaOZBpKqsAOj0fHpAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=Shalhevet%20Pass&f=false|title=Center of the storm: a case study of human rights abuses in Hebron District|publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]]|ISBN=1-56432-260-2|year= 2001|author=Peter Bouckaert|accessdate=16 March 2011|pages=64–65}}{{cite web|url=http://www.education.gov.il/children/page_23.htm|quote=In the afternoon, Yitzhak and Orya Pass took a walk with their daughter Shalhevet from their home in the Beit Hadassah neighborhood to the Avraham Avinu neighborhood where Orya’s parents lived. They heard shots when they reached the entrance to the Avraham Avinu neighborhood. Yitzhak fell.|title=Target: Israeli Children|publisher=[[Education Minister of Israel|Israeli Ministry of Education]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131023202452/http://www.education.gov.il/children/page_23.htm|archivedate=2013-10-23|df=}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=69IFhGwrwAAC&pg=PR13&dq=Shalhevet+Pass&hl=en&ei=JUCBTejXGJK8sAPv3tmDAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=Shalhevet%20Pass&f=false|title=Where's My Miracle?|author=Morey Schwartz|date=26 March 2001|accessdate=16 March 2011}} A Palestinian sniper resumed firing, after a ten-minute lull, from the Abu Sneinah neighborhood on the hill opposite. Shalhevet was killed instantly.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U9boAAAAIAAJ&q=Shalhevet+Pass&dq=Shalhevet+Pass&hl=en&ei=GEWBTcaYCYfksQO43YHmAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwADgo|title=Israel: Life In The Shadow Of Terror|author1=Nechemia Coopersmith |author2=Shraga Simmons |accessdate=16 March 2011}} The baby's mother grabbed her when she heard the gunshots, only to discover that the child was already dead.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} One of the sniper's bullets penetrated the baby's head, passing through her skull, and hit her father as well.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9FTxoncXDwwC&pg=PA443&dq=Shalhevet+Pass&hl=en&ei=JUCBTejXGJK8sAPv3tmDAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAjgK#v=onepage&q=Shalhevet%20Pass&f=false |title=Protection of children during armed political conflict: a multidisciplinary perspective|author1=Charles W. Greenbaum |author2=Philip E. Veerman |author3=Naomi Bacon-Shnoor |year=2006|accessdate=16 March 2011}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y7glZcS7mMgC&pg=PA190&dq=Shalhevet+Pass&hl=en&ei=JUCBTejXGJK8sAPv3tmDAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=Shalhevet%20Pass&f=false|title=Home to Stay: One American Family's Chronicle of Miracles and Struggles in Contemporary Israel|publisher= Random House|author=Daniel Gordis|year=2003|accessdate=16 March 2011}} Shalhevet's father, Yitzchak Pass, a student, who had been pushing the stroller, was also seriously wounded minutes later by two bullets.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Dxno8wNLIXEC&pg=PA171&dq=Shalhevet+Pass&hl=en&ei=szqBTaOZBpKqsAOj0fHpAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=Shalhevet%20Pass&f=false|title=Jerusalem diaries: in tense times|year=2001|author=Judy Lash Balint|accessdate=16 March 2011}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0LdyAAAAMAAJ&q=Shalhevet+Pass&dq=Shalhevet+Pass&hl=en&ei=i0OBTbTdApSksQO0ubD_AQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwADge|title=Lost years: Bush, Sharon, and failure in the Middle East|year=2007|author=Mark Matthews|accessdate=16 March 2011}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N8b9FGJ-WfkC&pg=PA9&dq=Shalhevet+Pass&hl=en&ei=zEWBTbPQMpPmsQOki93_AQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CEYQ6AEwCDgy#v=onepage&q=Shalhevet%20Pass&f=false|title=The Link|author=Nachman Seltzer|year=2006|accessdate=16 March 2011}} Press accounts indicated that the playground was very busy at the time, because a load of new sand had recently been delivered. According to unconfirmed accounts, another child was grazed by a bullet and two more had bullets pass through their clothing. ==Aftermath== [[File:Shalhevet Tchia'a Pass tombstonein.jpg|thumb|Tombstone of Shalhevet Pass]] The murder, which occurred during the [[Second Intifada]], produced vocal outrage in Israel and abroad. The nation mourned the killing of the baby.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} Prime Minister [[Ariel Sharon]] condemned the attack and sent his condolences to the Pass family. Sharon also stated that he saw the Palestinian Authority as responsible for the attack. The Jewish community in Hebron demanded that the Israeli army reoccupy the Abu Sneineh neighborhood in Hebron, and the Pass family even stated that they would not bury their baby until the IDF would reoccupy the Abu Sneineh neighborhood. ===Capture and trial of killer=== The Palestinian Authority initially arrested the sniper but released him after a short while. On 9 December 2002 the [[Shin Bet]] managed to capture the sniper – the [[Tanzim]] member Mahmud Amru. In December 2004 a military court convicted the killer and sentenced him to three life terms.BBC Monitoring Newsfile, 16 December 2004, quoting Ma'ariv web site, Tel Aviv, in English; accessed 12 August 2015.{{cite web|title=Baby's murderer gets three life sentences|publisher=Jerusalem Post|date=16 December 2004|author=Margot Dudkevitch|page=2}} According to the Israeli government, an investigation concluded that the sniper had intentionally targeted the baby.{{cite web|url=http://www.education.gov.il/children/page_23.htm|quote=On Monday, 26 March 2001, a Palestinian sniper aimed his rifle and opened fire at 10-month old Shalhevet Pass in Hebron, while she was lying in her stroller. Shalhevet was killed by a bullet to the head.|title=Target: Israeli Children|publisher=[[Education Minister of Israel|Israeli Ministry of Education]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131023202452/http://www.education.gov.il/children/page_23.htm|archivedate=23 October 2013|df=}} A spokesperson for Prime Minister [[Ariel Sharon]] said:
The fact that they could pick off the baby and then the father makes this a hideous, deliberate, cold-blooded murder. Snipers are not just gun-toting youth... If Arafat had wanted, the sniper would not have been there.
In the verdict the judges expressed their shock of the brutality of the murder:
"It was enough for one bullet, fired from a sniper rifle, to end the life of the infant Shalhevet Pass, who up to that event was unknown to the wide public, and just lived her life as all other children, until one day as the evening came she was hit in her head, and she died, and Shalhevet whom was still small and in her infant stage, was sentenced to death by a vile killer whom intentionally, using a [[Telescopic sight]], pulled the trigger. The picture of the shot baby is on our table, is engraved in our minds and does not give peace to our souls. We cannot understand and we cannot accept the unbearable ease with which the killer decided to harm a helpless person... We the judges are only humans and we cannot see anything else but the image which emerges in our senses, an image full of hate, blood and bereavement. We must not accept this image and we need to do everything we can to condemn it."
[[File:memorial-shalhevet-pass.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Memorial to Shalhevet Pass, Hebron]] The child's father, Yitzchak Pass, later joined the [[Bat Ayin|Bat Ayin Underground]] terrorist group which planned to blow up a Palestinian girls' school in East Jerusalem and was eventually arrested and convicted for possession of 10 pounds of explosive. He served a two-year prison sentence.[http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/83786#.Vcuo_3FVh8M Pass released from prison], israelnationalnews.com; accessed 12 August 2015. ==Reactions in the media== The [[Associated Press]] ran the story with the headline "Jewish toddler dies in West Bank"{{cite news|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-42968508.html|title=Jewish Toddler Dies in West Agony of the Promised Land|author=Joshua Levy|publisher=iUniverse|year=2004|accessdate=8 January 2013}} The ''[[Voice of Palestine]]'', the [[Palestinian Authority]]'s official radio station, reported magazine|year=2001|accessdate=16 March 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/15406/palestinian-radio-reports-israeli-mother-killed-baby|title=Palestinian radio reports Israeli {{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox comedian| | name = Paul Foot | image = Paul Foot Parkteatret Crap åppå Park (213202).jpg | caption = Foot on stage at the Crap Comedy Festival in 2017 | pseudonym = | birth_name = Paul Foot | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1973|12|24}} | birth_place = [[Amersham]], Buckinghamshire | medium = Stand-up, television | nationality = British | active = 1997–present | genre = | spouse = | alma_mater = [[Merton College, Oxford]] | website = {{URL|paulfoot.tv}} }} '''Paul Foot''' (born 24 December 1973) is an English comedian. Foot is known for his musings, rants, "disturbances" and apparent aversion to pop culture. The ''[[Daily Express]]'' likened him to "a rare exotic bird",<ref>{{cite web|last=Goulder |first=Claudia |url=https://www.express.co.uk/entertainment/theatre/120596/Paul-Foot-By-The-Yard-The-Underbelly-Edinburgh-Festival|title=Paul Foot – By The Yard: The Underbelly, Edinburgh Festival |work=[[Daily Express]] |date=15 August 2009 |access-date=16 August 2014}}</ref> and six national newspapers including ''[[The Independent]]'' and ''[[The Age]]'' have described him as "a comedy genius".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/comedy/features/cultural-life-rhod-gilbert-comedian-2177716.html | location=London | work=The Independent | title=Cultural Life: Rhod Gilbert, comedian | date=7 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="Ash in the Attic">{{cite news| url=http://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/comedy/ash-in-the-attic-20110406-1d3c6.html | location=Melbourne | work=The Age | title=Ash in the Attic | date=6 April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paulfoot.tv/press_quotes.php |title=Press Quotes |publisher=Paulfoot.tv |access-date=16 August 2014}}</ref>
==Biography== Foot was born and raised in [[Amersham]], Buckinghamshire, and has a younger brother.<ref name="Timeout">{{cite news|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/comedy/features/2022/Paul_Foot-Interview.html|title=Paul Foot: Interview|last=Hay|first=Malcolm|date=25 September 2006|work=Time Out London|access-date=14 October 2010}}</ref><ref name=BBCLeeds>{{BBC programme|id=p028lpwz|title=BBC Leeds – One on One, 28/10/2014, Paul Foot}}</ref> He studied mathematics at [[Merton College, Oxford]].<ref name="Indie">{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/comedy-adrian-mole-meets-emo-phillips-1291494.html|title=Comedy: Adrian Mole meets Emo Phillips|last=Conchie|first=Peter|date=1 November 1997|work=The Independent|publisher=Independent Print|access-date=14 October 2010|location=London}}</ref> It was during his studies that he first started performing stand-up.<ref name="Futon">{{cite press release|title=The Twelve Funniest Comedy Acts in the World Are Revealed on NBC's ''Last Comic Standing''|publisher=NBC|date=7 July 2008 |url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news.aspx?id=20080707nbc01 |accessdate=14 October 2010}}</ref> As of 2011, Foot has refused to discuss his years at Oxford or former pursuits as a mathematics student.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beatmagazine.co.uk/taking-comedy-to-the-next-level-an-interview-with-paul-foot|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222163706/http://www.beatmagazine.co.uk/taking-comedy-to-the-next-level-an-interview-with-paul-foot |title=Taking comedy to the next level – an interview with Paul Foot|archivedate=22 February 2014|work=Beat}}</ref> Graduating from Oxford in 1995, Foot was head-hunted by a computer software company in the run-up to the [[dot-com bubble]], however he loathed the industry: "I had to read manuals on HTML and just write websites from scratch. None of us really knew what we were doing".<ref name="leedsstudent.org">{{cite web|url=http://jackcullen.blogspot.co.uk/2010/10/interview-with-comedian-paul-foot.html|title=Jack of Hearts: An Interview with Comedian Paul Foot |author=Jack Cullen}}</ref> He started to pursue a career in comedy by doing [[open mic]] slots at various venues.<ref name="leedsstudent.org"/>
He is openly gay.<ref>{{cite web|author=Paul Foot |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xoW415APMzY&t=1m27s |title=Paul Foot – Levels of Homophobia |via=YouTube |date=13 February 2011 |accessdate=16 August 2014}}</ref> He has been described as "a little bit vegetarian", but has said that occasionally he does return to eating meat due to nutrition-related health issues.<ref name=BBCLeeds /> He has stated on his video log that he has [[prosopagnosia|face blindness]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Paul Foot|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m8aMHdzmpps|title=Paul Foot Video Log – Intellectual Rigour|via=YouTube|date=11 December 2015|access-date=5 August 2016}}</ref>
==Live performances== Foot frequently performs live, with resident slots at various London comedy clubs, and his fans sometimes demand shows in particularly obscure parts of Britain. He usually takes a show to the [[Edinburgh Fringe]] such as ''By the Yard'' (2009), ''Ash in the Attic'' (2010) (which was directed by [[Noel Fielding]]) and ''Words ''(2013).
Following Edinburgh, Foot usually tours Britain with his current show before taking it to Australia after Christmas for the Australian festival circuit. He has also given runs at Montreal Comedy festival as well as selling out at venues in Sweden.
In 2003, Foot and [[Russell Brand]] appeared in a double act at Cafe Royal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.festivalhighlights.com/2004/paulfoot/PaulFootPR.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308053439/http://www.festivalhighlights.com/2004/paulfoot/PaulFootPR.pdf |title=Paul Foot: Simple Pleasures |archivedate=8 March 2012}}</ref> Foot's style of comedy had a strong influence on Brand, who was inspired by Foot's eccentric hair, quirky mannerisms and love for florid language. In ''[[The Guardian]]'', Paul MacInnes wrote about their similarities in an article that explored the notion of "copycat comedians".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2009/sep/11/stewart-lee-jack-whitehall-comedians | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Paul | last=MacInnes | title=Stewart Lee, Jack Whitehall and the trouble with copycat comedians | date=11 September 2009}}</ref> Bruce Dessau made similar observations in ''[[Evening Standard|The Standard]]''.<ref>{{cite web|first=Bruce |last=Dessau |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/comedy/review-23432870-cult-stardom-could-be-a-hairs-breadth-away.do |title=Cult stardom could be a hair's breadth away |work=[[London Evening Standard]] |date=17 January 2008 |access-date=16 August 2014}}</ref>
Although a sector of Foot's fan base felt Brand had stolen Foot's act, the two comedians have remained friends. In 2012, Brand made a special appearance at one of Foot's ''Secret Shows'' and they improvised a play in which Brand played Foot and Foot played actress [[Angela Lansbury]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Paul Foot |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qplegHsxin0 |title=Paul Foot and Russell Brand Celebrity Coach Trip |via=YouTube |date=7 June 2012 |access-date=16 August 2014}}</ref>

2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://edinburghfestival.list.co.uk/article/28474-paul-foot-and-noel-fielding/|title=Paul Foot & Noel Fielding|date=17 August 2010|publisher=List.co.uk|access-date=13 April 2017}}</ref> and enjoyed two sell-out runs at London's [[Soho Theatre]] in February 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allgigs.co.uk/view/event/341862/Paul_Foot_Soho_Theatre_Studio_London_4_February_2011.html |title=Buy Paul Foot Tickets for All 2014 and 2015 UK Tour Dates and Concerts |publisher=All Gigs |access-date=16 August 2014}}</ref> ''Ash in the Attic'' was then taken to Melbourne for the 2011 [[Melbourne International Comedy Festival]] as part of the official gala web|url=http://www.comedyfestival.com.au/2011/season/shows/paul-foot-ash-in-the-attic|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928015911/http://www.comedyfestival.com.au/2011/season/shows/paul-foot-ash-in-the-attic|title=Paul August 2014}}</ref>
==''Still Life''== Foot performed eight secret London previews for his 2011 Edinburgh show ''Still Life'' before taking it to the Fringe where the show had a sell-out run at the Underbelly.<ref name="paulfoot.tv">{{cite web|url=http://www.paulfoot.tv/show_diary.php |title=Show diary |publisher=Paulfoot.tv |date=31 October 2011 |access-date=16 August 2014}}</ref> Foot toured the UK in autumn 2011 with ''Still Life'' starting at the Soho Theatre on 26 September.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thelowry.com/event/the-paul-foot-experience|title=Event Detail – The Paul Foot Experience – The Paul Foot Experience}}</ref> Foot took ''Still Life'' to the 2012 [[Melbourne International Comedy Festival]] where he starred in the [[Comedy Festival Gala]] on Australia's [[Network Ten]] and was nominated for a [[Barry Award (for comedy)|Barry Award]].<ref name="guardian.co.uk">{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2012/apr/17/uk-comedians-melbourne-comedy-festival | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Matt | last=Trueman | title=UK comedians lead the way at Melbourne festival | date=17 April 2012}}</ref> ''Still Life'' also featured at the [[Just for Laughs]] festival in Montreal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thebirminghampress.com/2012/10/paul-foot-the-comedian-at-the-glee/|title=Paul Foot – the comedian – at The Glee|work=The Birmingham Press}}</ref> The poster image for ''Still Life'' is an original artwork, a portrait of Foot amidst various fruits, by Victoria Brook.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paulfoot.tv/page5.php |title=Shop |publisher=Paulfoot.tv |date=19 December 2011 |access-date=16 August 2014}}</ref>
==Kenny Larch Is Dead== Foot's 2012 Edinburgh show was called ''Kenny Larch Is Dead''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/shows/edinburgh_fringe_2012/p/20362/paul_foot%3A_kenny_larch_is_dead |title=Paul Foot: Kenny Larch Is Dead's description |publisher=Chortle : The UK Comedy Guide |accessdate=16 August 2014}}</ref> As ever with Foot, the show had nothing to do with the title. Following the Fringe the sell-out show toured Britain, before being taken to the [[Melbourne International Comedy Festival]].<ref>[http://www.comedyfestival.com.au/2013/season/shows/kenny-larch-is-dead-paul-foot Kenny Larch is Dead, Paul Foot | Melbourne International Comedy Festival 2013] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130323051033/http://www.comedyfestival.com.au/2013/season/shows/kenny-larch-is-dead-paul-foot |date=23 March 2013 }}</ref> The show won the Best of Fest award at the Sydney Comedy festival,<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2013/may/13/paul-foot-sydney-comedy-festival-award | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Matt | last=Trueman | title=Paul Foot wins Sydney Comedy festival's international award | date=13 May 2013}}</ref> and Best International Show at the Perth comedy awards.
==Secret shows== In September 2006, Foot started a regular London-based solo variety show called ''Paul Foot's Comedy for Connoisseurs''. The title comes from the name given to his fans, "The Guild of Paul Foot Connoisseurs", for whom Foot arranges "secret" events advertised only via his official website and mailing list.<ref name=Timeout/><ref name="Secretshows">{{cite web|url=http://paulfoot.tv/secret.html|title=Paul Foot's Secret Shows|last=Foot|first=Paul|work=The Guild of Paul Foot Connoisseurs|accessdate=14 October 2010}}</ref> In the secret shows Foot often enters a surreal territory, taking on the personae of his own character creations such as "Penny" and "Skeleton Johnson", and sometimes improvising elaborate mini-dramas in which he plays all of the parts. Some of Foot's characters feature on his website which also has a secret page for his Guild of Connoisseurs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paulfoot.tv/ |title=The Guild of Paul Foot Connoisseurs |publisher=Paulfoot.tv |accessdate=16 August 2014}}</ref>
Foot's television appearances in 2010 introduced a new generation to his style of comedy, leading some "Connoisseurs of The Guild of Paul Foot Connoisseurs" unable to attend Foot's Secret Shows due to this new wave of popularity with a younger, student demographic booking them out. Foot addressed this problem by organising his first "Secret Secret Show" for his longest-serving fans. The show was not advertised anywhere on his website.<ref name="paulfoot.tv"/>
==The Paul Foot Festival== {{BLP sources section|date=September 2016}} In 2009, Paul Foot hosted his own all-day festival at Bethnal Green Working Men's Club in East London with the help of arts and music collective HungaMunga. Sketches included 'Foot of the Yard', a whodunnit, an Invisible Man Contest, Flamingo I-Spy, an Erotic Menu, and Paul's Rants. HungaMunga provided lots of arts and crafts materials and activities. Foot also painted portraits of members of the audience. The festival also included Paul's Protégé's featuring the comedians Tom Bell and Joel Dommett. Musical performers at the festival were Birmingham gonzo-ska band Misty's Big Adventure and Antony Elvin.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RnRD-DKDc60|title=Misty's Big Adventure – The Wising Up Song (part)|last=jfinchiva|date=13 July 2009|accessdate=13 April 2017|via=YouTube}}</ref>
==Television== Foot has appeared on numerous television shows including: * ''[[FAQ U]]'' (Channel Four) * ''Edinburgh and Beyond'' (Paramount Comedy Channel) * ''[[Rob Brydon's Annually Retentive]]'' (BBC Three) * ''[[Come Dine With Me]]'' (Channel 4) * ''[[Richard & Judy]]'' (Channel 4) * ''[[Never Mind the Buzzcocks]]'' (BBC Two)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b016z920 |title=Never Mind the Buzzcocks, Series 25, Episode 5 |publisher=BBC Two |date=7 November 2011 |access-date=16 August 2014}}</ref> * ''Russell & Katy Get Married'' (FIVE) * ''[[Big Brother's Big Mouth]]'' (Channel 4)<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1714290/ |title=Paul Foot |publisher=IMDb |year=2014 |access-date=16 August 2014}}</ref> * ''The 50 Funniest Moments of 2010'' (Channel 4)<ref name="imdb.com">{{cite web |url= https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1823754/ |title=The 50 Funniest Moments of 2010 |publisher=IMDb |year=2014 |accessdate=16 August 2014}}</ref> * ''Greatest Christmas TV Ads'' (FIVE)<ref name="imdb.com"/> * ''Melbourne International Comedy Festival All Star Supershow'' (Channel Ten – Australia) * ''[[Russell Howard's Good News Extra]]'' (BBC Three) * ''[[8 out of 10 Cats]]'' (Channel 4) * ''[[Would I Lie to You? (TV series)|Would I Lie To You]]'' (BBC One)
In 2008, Foot was a finalist in NBC's ''[[Last Comic Standing]]''.<ref name="NBC">{{cite web|url=http://www.nbc.com/Last_Comic_Standing/finalists/paul-foot.shtml|title=''Last Comic Standing'' Finalist: Paul Foot|publisher=NBC.com|access-date=14 October 2010}}</ref>
In 2011, Foot filmed a series of TV advertisements for Virgin Mobile in Australia. He helped to devise his character in the campaign called "Robin Da Hood", a bizarre fusion of medieval eccentricities and modern-day Australian urbanity. The first of these adverts featured an emergency phone conversation between Foot and head of the [[Virgin Group]] Sir [[Richard Branson]].
==Awards== In 1997, Foot won both the [[BBC New Comedy Awards|BBC New Stand-up Award]] and the ''Daily Telegraph'' Open Mic Award, and was a finalist for the [[So You Think You're Funny]] award for newcomers.<ref name="Chortle">{{cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/comics/p/403/paul_foot|title=Paul Foot|work=Chortle: The UK Comedy Guide|access-date=14 October 2010}}</ref> In 1998, he was nominated for the Perrier Best Newcomer Award in Edinburgh.
In 2011, Foot was nominated for a [[Barry Award (for comedy)|Barry Award]] at the [[Melbourne International Comedy Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Craig |last=Platt |url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/entertainment/comedy/blogs/last-laugh/barry-award-nominees-announced-20110417-1djfk.html |title=2011 Barry Award nominees |work=[[Brisbane Times]] |access-date=16 August 2014}}</ref> In 2012, Foot was nominated again for a [[Barry Award (for comedy)|Barry Award]] at the [[Melbourne International Comedy Festival]].<ref name="guardian.co.uk"/> In 2013, Foot won the top award at the Sydney Comedy festival for Kenny Larch Is Dead, which won the best show award.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
==Paul Foot Podcast== Since 2009, Foot has released a podcast, the ''Paul Foot Podcast''. It was originally the highlights from his show on [[Resonance FM]], and featured fellow stand-up comedian [[Joel Dommett]], among other regulars. After the Resonance FM show ended, a few episodes were released independently up to May 2010. Episodes of the podcast then became more sporadic, being released every few months or so; these episodes included guests such as [[Trevor Lock]] and Paul's tour support act Malcolm Head, as well as recordings from Paul's Secret Shows. Starting in 2015, the podcast started being released far more regularly once again, with another stand-up comedian, Tom Mayhew, as co-host.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://paulfoot.podbean.com/ |title=Podcast homepage |publisher=Paulfoot.tv |access-date=5 February 2016|date=1 February 2016}}</ref>
==Guild of Connoisseurs== He commands a significant cult following called ''The Guild of Connoisseurs''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paulfoot.tv/guild.php |title=Guild Lodge |publisher=Paulfoot.tv |accessdate=16 August 2014}}</ref> As well as secret stand-up comedy shows Foot arranges events for The Guild of Connoisseurs such as secret picnics, spoof lectures and guided tours. In July 2011 he scheduled an event at Stepney City Farm at which connoisseurs attempted to complete a 32,000 piece jigsaw puzzle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paulfoot.tv/page6.php |title=Shop |publisher=Paulfoot.tv |date=19 December 2011 |access-date=16 August 2014}}</ref>
Foot hosts competitions within the Guild too, such as an annual tie design competition and portrait painting competitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paulfoot.tv/page1.php |title=Shop |publisher=Paulfoot.tv |date=19 December 2011 |accessdate=16 August 2014}}</ref>

'''Peter Marshall''' (born 12 May 1971 in [[Nottingham]], [[United Kingdom]]) is a former professional [[squash (sport)|squash]] player from [[England]].
With his unique double-handed playing style, Marshall finished runner-up to the great [[Pakistan]]i player [[Jansher Khan]] at the [[World Open (squash)|World Open]] in 1994 and the [[British Open Squash Championships|British Open]] in 1995. When he reached the World No. 2 ranking behind Jansher in November 1994, many observers felt he seemed a strong candidate to displace the aging Pakistani champion as World No. 1. However, in 1995, Marshall was afflicted with [[glandular fever]], the effects of which meant he was unable to play top-level squash for two years.<ref>{{cite news |title=Squash: Marshall's rebellion within |first=Iain |last=Fletcher |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/squash-marshalls-rebellion-within-1235500.html |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=12 October 1997 |accessdate=21 December 2010}}</ref>
Marshall returned to the professional tour in 1997, re-claiming his place in the England squad which went on to win the [[World Team Squash Championships]] title in [[Malaysia]]. He broke back into the world's top-10 in 1999, and won his third [[British National Squash Championships|British National Championship]] title in February 2000. He was protecting a remarkable record, having been unbeaten in that event since December 1989.
== Early career == Marshall won British junior titles at all age-groups (under-12, under-14, under-16 and under-19). He first became England's No.1 in November 1991, holding the position unchallenged for four years.
In 1989, Marshall won the British Open U19. The following year, he became World Masters U23 Champion.
His first full year of international competition was 1991, but it was in the 1994-95 season that Marshall's promise was most powerfully demonstrated. He was a finalist in five [[PSA Super Series]] events leading up to and including the 1995 British Open.
Marshall was British and European No 1 for several years.
== After retiring from the professional tour == Marshall released an [[autobiography]] about his battle against [[chronic fatigue syndrome]] in 2001 entitled ''Shattered: A Champion's Fight Against a Mystery Illness''.<ref name="marshall2001">{{cite book |last= Marshall |first= Peter |title= Shattered: A Champion's Fight Against a Mystery Illness |publisher= [[Mainstream Publishing]] |date=March 2001 |isbn= 978-1-84018-395-5}} </ref>
Marshall has a BSc in Physiotherapy from the [[University of Nottingham]] and an Executive MBA from [[Imperial College London]]. He currently works for [[Ernst & Young]].
In 2008, Marshall won the Over-35 British National Championship in Manchester. He also won the British Open Masters Over-40 in 2016 and 2018.
Marshall is an Ambassador for Access Sport, a charity focused on providing children from disadvantaged areas with access to local sports and promoting the real difference sport can make within deprived communities.
He is also a trustee for the England Squash Foundation, a national charity with a vision to enhance young people's lives through squash.
In May 2015, Marshall was given a Lifetime Achievement Award at the World Squash Awards for his achievements, continued support and commitment to the game.
